Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

Posted on 2019-03-18 Edited on 2019-03-22

The relation between integration and differentiation constitutes the key study of calculus.

Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

  1. If f:[a,b]→f : [a, b] \rightarrowf:[a,b]→ is bounded and Riemann integrable, and F(x)=∫axf(t) dtF(x) = \int_a^x f(t) \ dtF(x)=∫ax​f(t) dt for x∈[a,b]x \in [a, b]x∈[a,b], then F(x)F(x)F(x) is uniformly continuous and F′(x)F'(x)F′(x) exists for all xxx where f(x)f(x)f(x) is continuous and F′(x)=f(x)F'(x) = f(x)F′(x)=f(x).
  2. If F:[a,b]→RF: [a, b] \rightarrow RF:[a,b]→R is differentiable and f:[a,b]→Rf: [a, b] \rightarrow Rf:[a,b]→R is integrable. Suppose F′(x)=f(x)F'(x) = f(x)F′(x)=f(x) for all x∈[a,b]x \in [a, b]x∈[a,b], then

F(b)−F(a)=∫abf(t) dtF(b) - F(a) = \int_a^b f(t) \ dt F(b)−F(a)=∫ab​f(t) dt

Remark:

  1. Claim one require the condition that fff is bounded. Can we omit the condition?

  2. The condition fff is integrable is necessary.

Proof:

  1. As fff is bounded, we assume that sup⁡t∈[a,b]∣f(t)∣≤M\sup_{t \in [a, b]} |f(t)| \le Msupt∈[a,b]​∣f(t)∣≤M. For any x∈[a,b]x \in [a, b]x∈[a,b] and x+h∈[a,b]x + h \in [a, b]x+h∈[a,b],

    ∣F(x+h)−F(x)∣=∣∫xx+hf(t) dt∣≤M∣h∣\left| F(x + h) - F(x) \right| = \left| \int_x^{x + h} f(t) \ dt \right| \le M|h| ∣F(x+h)−F(x)∣=∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫xx+h​f(t) dt∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤M∣h∣

    This show that F(x)F(x)F(x) is uniformly continuous.

    Now, assume that f(x)f(x)f(x) is continuous at point xxx. ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃δ>0\exists \delta > 0∃δ>0, s.t., ∀t∈(x±δ)\forall t \in (x \pm \delta)∀t∈(x±δ), ∣f(t)−f(x)∣≤ϵ|f(t) - f(x)| \le \epsilon∣f(t)−f(x)∣≤ϵ. We see that

    ∣F(x+h)−F(x)−f(x)h∣=∣∫xx+hf(t) dt−∫xx+hf(x) dt∣=∣∫xx+h[f(t)−f(x)] dt∣≤∫xx+h∣f(t)−f(x)∣ dt≤ϵh\begin{aligned} \left| F(x + h) - F(x) - f(x) h \right| &= \left| \int_x^{x + h} f(t) \ dt - \int_x^{x + h} f(x) \ dt \right| \\ &= \left| \int_x^{x + h} [f(t) - f(x)] \ dt \right| \\ &\le \int_x^{x + h} \left| f(t) - f(x) \right| \ dt \\ &\le \epsilon h \end{aligned} ∣F(x+h)−F(x)−f(x)h∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫xx+h​f(t) dt−∫xx+h​f(x) dt∣∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫xx+h​[f(t)−f(x)] dt∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫xx+h​∣f(t)−f(x)∣ dt≤ϵh​

    As desired.

  2. For partition P={a=x0<x1<x2<...<xn=b}P = \{ a = x_0 < x_1 < x_2 < ... < x_n = b \}P={a=x0​<x1​<x2​<...<xn​=b} of [a,b][a, b][a,b], apply the mean value theorem to FFF on a sub-interval.

    F(xk)−F(xk−1)=F′(tk)(xk−xk−1)tk∈[xk−1,xk]∀ 1≤k≤n,F(x_k) - F(x_{k - 1}) = F'(t_k) (x_k - x_{k -1}) \quad t_k \in [x_{k - 1}, x_k] \quad \forall \ 1 \le k \le n, F(xk​)−F(xk−1​)=F′(tk​)(xk​−xk−1​)tk​∈[xk−1​,xk​]∀ 1≤k≤n,

    Let U(f,P),L(f,)U(f, P), L(f, )U(f,P),L(f,) be the upper sum and lower sum of the partition respectively,

    F(b)−F(a)=∑k=1nF(xk)−F(xk−1)=∑k=1nF′(tk)(xk−xk−1)=∑k=1nf(tk)(xk−xk−1)∈[L(f,P),U(f,P)]\begin{aligned} F(b) - F(a) &= \sum_{k = 1}^n F(x_k) - F(x_{k - 1}) \\ &= \sum_{k = 1}^n F'(t_k) (x_k - x_{k -1}) \\ &= \sum_{k = 1}^n f(t_k) (x_k - x_{k -1}) \\ &\in [L(f, P), U(f, P)] \end{aligned} F(b)−F(a)​=k=1∑n​F(xk​)−F(xk−1​)=k=1∑n​F′(tk​)(xk​−xk−1​)=k=1∑n​f(tk​)(xk​−xk−1​)∈[L(f,P),U(f,P)]​

    This is independent of the choice of PPP. Taking the limit of upper sum and lower sum, we conclude that F(b)−F(a)∈[sup⁡PL(f,P),inf⁡PU(f,P)]=[∫abf(t) dt,∫abf(t) dt]F(b) - F(a) \in [\sup_P L(f, P), \inf_P U(f, P)] = \left[ \int_a^b f(t) \ dt, \int_a^b f(t) \ dt \right]F(b)−F(a)∈[supP​L(f,P),infP​U(f,P)]=[∫ab​f(t) dt,∫ab​f(t) dt].

Radon Nikodym Theorem

Posted on 2019-03-14 Edited on 2022-09-29

We consider a measure space (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ), where Ω\OmegaΩ is a set of elements, F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-field, and μ:F→R\mu : \mathcal{F} \rightarrow Rμ:F→R a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure defined on F\mathcal{F}F.

Definition (Mutually Singular). Measures μ\muμ and ν\nuν on a measurable space (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathcal{F})(Ω,F) are by definition mutually singular if they have disjoint supports, i.e., if

∃Sμ,Sν∈F,  s.t.  {Sμ∩Sν=∅, μ(Sˉμ)=ν(Sˉν)=0. \exists S_\mu, S_\nu \in \mathcal{F},\, \text{ s.t. }\, \begin{cases} S_\mu \cap S_\nu = \emptyset,\, \\ \mu(\bar S_\mu) = \nu(\bar S_\nu) = 0. \end{cases} ∃Sμ​,Sν​∈F, s.t. {Sμ​∩Sν​=∅,μ(Sˉμ​)=ν(Sˉν​)=0.​

Definition (Absolute Continuous). Measure ν\nuν is absolute continuous with μ\muμ (or dominated by μ\muμ), denoted as ν≪μ\nu \ll \muν≪μ, if

μ(E)=0  ⟹  ν(E)=0,∀E∈F. \mu(E) = 0 \implies \nu(E) = 0, \qquad \forall E \in \mathcal{F}. μ(E)=0⟹ν(E)=0,∀E∈F.

Motivation. Let fff be a nonnegative and measurable function.
Then the measure defined by

ν(E)=∫Ef dμ,∀E∈F, \nu(E) = \int_E f \, d \mu, \qquad \forall E \in \mathcal{F}, ν(E)=∫E​fdμ,∀E∈F,

is absolutely continuous with respect to μ\muμ.
The The Radon-Nikodym Theorem establishes the opposite direction.

The Radon-Nikodym Theorem.
Let μ,ν\mu, \nuμ,ν be σ\sigmaσ-finite measures such that ν≪μ\nu \ll \muν≪μ.
There exists a nonnegative measurable function fff, a density, such that

ν(E)=∫Ef dμ,∀E∈F. \nu(E) = \int_E f \, d \mu, \qquad \forall E \in \mathcal{F}. ν(E)=∫E​fdμ,∀E∈F.

For two such function fff and f′f'f′, μ[f≠f′]=0\mu[ f \neq f' ] = 0μ[f=f′]=0.
fff is called the Radon-Nikodym derivative of ν\nuν with respect to μ\muμ and is denoted dμ/dνd \mu / d \nudμ/dν.

The proof of the Theorem relies on the following lemma, the proof of which is deferred to the end of the article.

Lemma. Let μ\muμ and ν\nuν be two finite measures that are not mutually singular.
Then there exits A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, such that μ(A)>0\mu(A) > 0μ(A)>0, and for each measurable set EEE in AAA, it holds that ϵ⋅μ(E)≤ν(E)\epsilon \cdot \mu(E) \le \nu(E)ϵ⋅μ(E)≤ν(E).

Proof of the Theorem:

Since both μ\muμ and ν\nuν are σ\sigmaσ-finite, there is a disjoint sequence En∈FE_n \in \mathcal{F}En​∈F such that ∪n≥1En=Ω\cup_{n \ge 1} E_n = \Omega∪n≥1​En​=Ω and that μ(En)<∞\mu(E_n) < \inftyμ(En​)<∞, ν(En)<∞\nu(E_n) < \inftyν(En​)<∞ for each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+.

Define finite measures μn\mu_nμn​ and νn\nu_nνn​ by

μn(E)=μ(E∩En),νn(E)=ν(E∩En),∀E∈F. \mu_n (E) = \mu(E \cap E_n),\quad \nu_n (E) = \nu(E \cap E_n),\quad \forall E \in \mathcal{F}. μn​(E)=μ(E∩En​),νn​(E)=ν(E∩En​),∀E∈F.

Suppose that we can find densities fn,n∈N+f_n, n \in \mathbb{N}^+fn​,n∈N+, such that νn(E)=∫Efn dμn\nu_n(E) = \int_E f_n \, d \mu_nνn​(E)=∫E​fn​dμn​.
As μn\mu_nμn​ has density 1En\mathbf{1}_{E_n}1En​​, for each E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F, it holds that ∫Efn dμn=∫Efn⋅1En dμ\int_E f_n \, d \mu_n = \int_E f_n \cdot \mathbf{1}_{E_n} \, d \mu∫E​fn​dμn​=∫E​fn​⋅1En​​dμ.
Via monotone convergence theorem,

μ(E)=∑n≥1μn(E)=∑n≥1∫Efn dμn=∑n≥1∫Efn⋅1En dμ=∫E∑n≥1fn⋅1En dμ. \begin{aligned} \mu(E) &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \mu_n(E) = \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_E f_n \, d \mu_n \\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_E f_n \cdot \mathbf{1}_{E_n} \, d \mu = \int_E \sum_{n \ge 1} f_n \cdot \mathbf{1}_{E_n} \, d \mu. \end{aligned} μ(E)​=n≥1∑​μn​(E)=n≥1∑​∫E​fn​dμn​=n≥1∑​∫E​fn​⋅1En​​dμ=∫E​n≥1∑​fn​⋅1En​​dμ.​

WLOG, we can assume that both μ\muμ and ν\nuν are finite.

Define the collection of functions

G={g is nonnegative, measurable and ∫Eg dμ≤ν(E),∀E∈F}. \mathcal{G} = \left\{ g \text{ is nonnegative, measurable and } \int_E g \, d \mu \le \nu(E), \quad \forall E \in \mathcal{F} \right\}. G={g is nonnegative, measurable and ∫E​gdμ≤ν(E),∀E∈F}.

Note that G\mathcal{G}G is non-empty, since at least g≡0g \equiv 0g≡0 satisfies the conditions and belongs to G\mathcal{G}G.
Moreover,

  • G\mathcal{G}G is closed under finite maxima: let g1,g2∈Gg_1, g_2 \in \mathcal{G}g1​,g2​∈G, then for each E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F,

    ∫Emax⁡(g1,g2) dμ=∫E∩[g1≥g2]g1 dμ+∫E∩[g1<g2]g2 dμ≤ν(E∩[g1≥g2])+ν(E∩[g1<g2])=ν(E). \begin{aligned} \int_E \max (g_1, g_2) \, d \mu &= \int_{E \cap [g_1 \ge g_2]} g_1 \, d \mu + \int_{E \cap [g_1 < g_2]} g_2 \, d \mu \\ &\le \nu \big( E \cap [g_1 \ge g_2] \big) + \nu \big( E \cap [g_1 < g_2] \big) = \nu (E). \end{aligned} ∫E​max(g1​,g2​)dμ​=∫E∩[g1​≥g2​]​g1​dμ+∫E∩[g1​<g2​]​g2​dμ≤ν(E∩[g1​≥g2​])+ν(E∩[g1​<g2​])=ν(E).​

  • G\mathcal{G}G is closed under non-decreasing limit: let gn∈Gg_n \in \mathcal{G}gn​∈G such that gn↑gg_n \uparrow ggn​↑g, then by monotone convergence theorem it holds for each E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F that

    lim⁡n∫Egn dμ=∫Elim⁡ngn dμ≤ν(E). \lim_n \int_E g_n \, d \mu = \int_E \lim_n g_n \, d \mu \le \nu(E). nlim​∫E​gn​dμ=∫E​nlim​gn​dμ≤ν(E).

Next, consider the supremum of integrals of function in G\mathcal{G}G:

α≐sup⁡g∈G∫g dμ≤ν(Ω)<∞. \alpha \doteq \sup_{g \in \mathcal{G} } \int g \ d \mu \le \nu(\Omega) < \infty. α≐g∈Gsup​∫g dμ≤ν(Ω)<∞.

Let gn∈G,n∈N+g_n \in \mathcal{G}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+gn​∈G,n∈N+ be a sequence of functions such that
lim⁡n∫gn dμ=α. \lim_n \int g_n \ d \mu = \alpha. limn​∫gn​ dμ=α.

For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, define fn=max⁡i∈[n]gif_n = \max_{i \in [n]} g_ifn​=maxi∈[n]​gi​.
Then the fnf_nfn​ is a non-decreasing sequence of functions in G\mathcal{G}G.
Denote f=lim⁡nfnf = \lim_n f_nf=limn​fn​.
We have f∈Gf \in \mathcal{G}f∈G, and

∫f dμ=lim⁡n∫gn dμ=α. \int f \, d \mu = \lim_n \int g_n \ d \mu = \alpha. ∫fdμ=nlim​∫gn​ dμ=α.

It is left to show that λ(E)=∫Ef\lambda(E) = \int_E fλ(E)=∫E​f for each measurable set EEE. Define function λ:F→R\lambda : \mathcal{F} \rightarrow Rλ:F→R as

λ(E)=ν(E)−∫Ef dμ \lambda(E) = \nu(E) - \int_E f \ d \mu λ(E)=ν(E)−∫E​f dμ

We complete the proof by showing that λ(E)≡0\lambda(E) \equiv 0λ(E)≡0.

It is easy to verify that λ\lambdaλ is a measure (λ≥0\lambda \ge 0λ≥0) as ν(E)≥∫Efdμ\nu(E) \ge \int_E f d \muν(E)≥∫E​fdμ. Further, ∫Ef dμ≪μ\int_E f \ d \mu \ll \mu∫E​f dμ≪μ and ν≪μ\nu \ll \muν≪μ imply that λ≪μ\lambda \ll \muλ≪μ.

Suppose λ≠0\lambda \ne 0λ=0. By assumption μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞, then there exists ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, such that λ(Ω)−ϵμ(Ω)>0\lambda(\Omega) - \epsilon \mu(\Omega) > 0λ(Ω)−ϵμ(Ω)>0. Let {A,B}\{ A, B\}{A,B} be the Hahn decomposition of λ−ϵμ\lambda - \epsilon \muλ−ϵμ such that AAA is positive. Let g=f+ϵχAg = f + \epsilon \chi_{A}g=f+ϵχA​. It satisfies

  1. g∈Gg \in \mathcal{G}g∈G, since ∀E∈F\forall E \in \mathcal{F}∀E∈F,

    λ(E)−∫Eg dμ=λ(E)−∫Ef dμ−∫EϵχA dμ≥0 \lambda(E) - \int_E g \ d \mu = \lambda(E) - \int_E f \ d \mu - \int_E \epsilon \chi_{A} \ d \mu \ge 0 λ(E)−∫E​g dμ=λ(E)−∫E​f dμ−∫E​ϵχA​ dμ≥0

  2. ∫g dμ≥α\int g \ d \mu \ge \alpha∫g dμ≥α,

    ∫g dμ=∫f+ϵχA dμ=∫f dμ+∫ϵχA dμ=α+ϵμ(A)≥α \int g \ d \mu = \int f + \epsilon \chi_{A} \ d \mu = \int f \ d \mu + \int \epsilon \chi_A \ d \mu = \alpha + \epsilon \mu(A) \ge \alpha ∫g dμ=∫f+ϵχA​ dμ=∫f dμ+∫ϵχA​ dμ=α+ϵμ(A)≥α

If follows that μ(A)=0\mu(A) = 0μ(A)=0. Now 0<(λ−ϵμ)(Ω)=(λ−ϵμ)(A)+(λ−ϵμ)(B)=0+(λ−ϵμ)(B)≤00 < (\lambda - \epsilon \mu)(\Omega) = (\lambda - \epsilon \mu)(A) + (\lambda - \epsilon \mu)(B) = 0 + (\lambda - \epsilon \mu)(B) \le 00<(λ−ϵμ)(Ω)=(λ−ϵμ)(A)+(λ−ϵμ)(B)=0+(λ−ϵμ)(B)≤0. Contradiction. We thus have proved that λ=0\lambda = 0λ=0.

□\square□

Proof of the Lemma.

For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, ν−(1/n)⋅μ\nu - (1 / n) \cdot \muν−(1/n)⋅μ is a signed measure.
Let Sn+,Sn−S_n^+, S_n^-Sn+​,Sn−​ be its Hahn decomposition.
Define S+=∪n≥1Sn+S^+ = \cup_{n \ge 1} S_n^+S+=∪n≥1​Sn+​, and S−=∩n≥1Sn−S^- = \cap_{n \ge 1} S_n^-S−=∩n≥1​Sn−​.
Since S−⊂Sn−S^- \subset S_n^-S−⊂Sn−​, we have

ν(S−)≤1n⋅μ(S−),∀n∈N+. \nu(S^-) \le \frac{1}{n} \cdot \mu(S^-), \qquad \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+. ν(S−)≤n1​⋅μ(S−),∀n∈N+.

It follows that ν(S−)=0\nu(S^-) = 0ν(S−)=0.
Since μ\muμ and ν\nuν are not mutually singular, S−S^-S− does not support μ\muμ.
Hence μ(S+)>0\mu(S^+) > 0μ(S+)>0.
There exits some n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, such that μ(Sn+)>0\mu(S_n^+) > 0μ(Sn+​)>0.
But

ν(E)≥1n⋅μ(E),∀E⊂Sn+,E∈F. \nu(E) \ge \frac{1}{n} \cdot \mu(E), \qquad \forall E \subset S_n^+, E \in \mathcal{F}. ν(E)≥n1​⋅μ(E),∀E⊂Sn+​,E∈F.

□\square□

Theorem (Chain Rule). Let μ1,μ2,μ3\mu_1, \mu_2, \mu_3μ1​,μ2​,μ3​ be σ\sigmaσ-finite measures on (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathcal{F})(Ω,F), s.t., μ1≪μ2\mu_1 \ll \mu_2μ1​≪μ2​, μ2≪μ3\mu_2 \ll \mu_3μ2​≪μ3​.
Prove that μ1≪μ3\mu_1 \ll \mu_3μ1​≪μ3​, and

dμ1dμ3(ω)=dμ1dμ2(ω)⋅dμ2dμ3(ω)a.e. with respect to  μ3. \frac{d \mu_1}{d \mu_3} (\omega) = \frac{d \mu_1}{d \mu_2} (\omega) \cdot \frac{d \mu_2}{d \mu_3} (\omega) \qquad \text{a.e. with respect to }\, \mu_3. dμ3​dμ1​​(ω)=dμ2​dμ1​​(ω)⋅dμ3​dμ2​​(ω)a.e. with respect to μ3​.

Proof. μ1≪μ3\mu_1 \ll \mu_3μ1​≪μ3​ is straightforward.

Next, to ease the notations, denote

f=dμ1dμ3,h=dμ1dμ2,δ=dμ2dμ3,g=h⋅δ. f = \frac{d \mu_1}{d \mu_3}, \quad h = \frac{d \mu_1}{d \mu_2}, \quad \delta = \frac{d \mu_2}{d \mu_3}, \quad g = h \cdot \delta. f=dμ3​dμ1​​,h=dμ2​dμ1​​,δ=dμ3​dμ2​​,g=h⋅δ.

Via Radon-Nikodym theorem, for each E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F, it holds that

μ1(E)=∫Ef dμ3,μ1(E)=∫Eh dμ2,μ2(E)=∫Eδ dμ3. \mu_1(E) = \int_E f \, d \mu_3, \quad \mu_1(E) = \int_E h \, d \mu_2, \quad \mu_2(E) = \int_E \delta \, d \mu_3. μ1​(E)=∫E​fdμ3​,μ1​(E)=∫E​hdμ2​,μ2​(E)=∫E​δdμ3​.

The goal is to prove that

Lemma.

∫Ef dμ3=μ1(E)=∫Eh⋅δ dμ3,∀E∈F. \int_E f \, d \mu_3 = \mu_1(E) = \int_E h \cdot \delta \, d \mu_3, \quad \forall E \in \mathcal{F}. ∫E​fdμ3​=μ1​(E)=∫E​h⋅δdμ3​,∀E∈F.

Define En+≐{f−h⋅δ≥1/n},∀n∈N+E^+_n \doteq \{ f - h \cdot \delta \ge 1 / n \}, \forall n \in \mathbb{N}^+En+​≐{f−h⋅δ≥1/n},∀n∈N+.
Then

0=∫En+(f−h⋅δ) dμ3≥1n⋅μ3(En+)  ⟹  μ3(En+)=0. 0 = \int_{E^+_n} (f - h \cdot \delta) \, d \mu_3 \ge \frac{1}{n} \cdot \mu_3 (E^+_n) \implies \mu_3 (E^+_n) = 0. 0=∫En+​​(f−h⋅δ)dμ3​≥n1​⋅μ3​(En+​)⟹μ3​(En+​)=0.

Let E+≐{f>h⋅δ}E^+ \doteq \{ f > h \cdot \delta \}E+≐{f>h⋅δ}.
Since En+↗EE_n^+ \nearrow EEn+​↗E, we get μ3(E+)=lim⁡nμ3(En+)=0\mu_3 (E^+) = \lim_n \mu_3 (E^+_n) = 0μ3​(E+)=limn​μ3​(En+​)=0.

In the same vein one can prove that μ3(f<h⋅δ)=0\mu_3 ( f < h \cdot \delta ) = 0μ3​(f<h⋅δ)=0.
It concludes that f=h⋅δf = h \cdot \deltaf=h⋅δ almost everywhere respect to μ3\mu_3μ3​.

Proof of the Lemma.

Consider a fixed E∈FE \in \mathcal{F}E∈F.

Case One. h=IS,S∈Fh = \mathbb{I}_S, S \in \mathcal{F}h=IS​,S∈F is an indicator random variable.
Then

∫EIS dμ2=μ2(E∩S)=∫E∩Sδ dμ3=∫EIS⋅δ dμ3. \int_E \mathbb{I}_S \, d \mu_2 = \mu_2(E \cap S) = \int_{E \cap S} \delta \, d \mu_3 = \int_E \mathbb{I}_S \cdot \delta \, d \mu_3. ∫E​IS​dμ2​=μ2​(E∩S)=∫E∩S​δdμ3​=∫E​IS​⋅δdμ3​.

Case Two. hhh is a simple function.
The claim follows from the linearity of expectation.

Case Two. hhh is a non-negative function. One can construct a sequence of simple functions which increases to hhh.
The claim follows from the monotone convergence theorem.

□\square□

Integral

Posted on 2019-03-03 Edited on 2021-06-19

We consider a measure space (X,Ω,μ)(X, \Omega, \mu)(X,Ω,μ), where XXX is a set of elements, Ω\OmegaΩ is a collection of measurable sets and μ:Ω→R\mu : \Omega \rightarrow Rμ:Ω→R a measure defined on μ\muμ. Note that by definition Ω\OmegaΩ is a σ\sigmaσ algebra and μ\muμ satisfies

  1. (Zero element) μ(∅)=0​\mu(\emptyset) = 0​μ(∅)=0​,
  2. (Non negativity) μ(E)≥0​\mu(E) \ge 0​μ(E)≥0​ for all E∈ΩE \in \OmegaE∈Ω,
  3. (σ\sigmaσ-additivity) μ(∪i≥1Ei)=∑i=1∞μ(Ei)\mu( \cup_{i \ge 1} E_i) = \sum_{i = 1}^\infty \mu(E_i)μ(∪i≥1​Ei​)=∑i=1∞​μ(Ei​) for a countable sequence of mutually disjoint sets {Ei}\{E_i\}{Ei​}.

Simple Function

A characteristic function [⋅]→{0,1}​[ \cdot ] \rightarrow \{0, 1\}​[⋅]→{0,1}​ is a function that takes value 1 if its argument is true and zero otherwise. A characteristic function χE:X→{0,1}​\chi_E : X \rightarrow \{0, 1\}​χE​:X→{0,1}​ for a set E⊂X​E \subset X​E⊂X​ is denoted as χE≐[x∈E]​\chi_E \doteq [x \in E]​χE​≐[x∈E]​.

A simple function f:X→Rf : X \rightarrow Rf:X→R is summation of finite terms:

f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i} f=i∈[n]∑​ai​χEi​​

where {E1,E2,...En}\{E_1, E_2,... E_n \}{E1​,E2​,...En​} are measurable sets and constitute a partition of XXX, i.e., ∪i∈[n]Ei=X\cup_{i \in [n] } E_i = X∪i∈[n]​Ei​=X and Ei∩Ej=∅E_i \cap E_j = \emptysetEi​∩Ej​=∅ for i≠ji \neq ji=j.

Simple Integrable Function

A simple function f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i }f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​ is said to be integrable if μ(Ei)<∞\mu(E_i ) < \inftyμ(Ei​)<∞ for all the indices iii for which ai≠0a_i \neq 0ai​=0, i.e., ai≠0→μ(Ei)<∞a_i \neq 0 \rightarrow \mu(E_i) < \inftyai​=0→μ(Ei​)<∞.
The integral of fff is the real number ∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei)\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i)∑i∈[n]​ai​μ(Ei​), where we agree to take aiμ(Ei)=0a_i \mu(E_i ) = 0ai​μ(Ei​)=0 for all the indices iii for which ai=0,μ(Ei)=∞a_i=0, \mu(E_i )= \inftyai​=0,μ(Ei​)=∞. We denote this sum by

∫f=∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei)\int f= \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i ) ∫f=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​)

Theorem The integration is well defined and independent of the representation of fff.

Proof. Let f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​ and g=∑j=1mbjχFjg = \sum_{j = 1}^m b_j \chi_{F_j}g=∑j=1m​bj​χFj​​. Suppose that f≡gf \equiv gf≡g, the goal is to show that ∫f=∫g\int f = \int g∫f=∫g. Define Sij=Ei∩FjS_{ij} = E_i \cap F_jSij​=Ei​∩Fj​. If Sij≠∅S_{ij} \neq \emptysetSij​=∅, we must have ai=bja_i = b_jai​=bj​. To see this, let s∈Si,js \in S_{i,j}s∈Si,j​. Since {E1,E2,...En}\{E_1, E_2,... E_n \}{E1​,E2​,...En​} is a partition of XXX,only one of the value {χEi(s):i∈[n]}\{ \chi_{E_i} (s) : i \in [n] \}{χEi​​(s):i∈[n]} takes value 1 and f(s)=∑i∈[n]aiχEi(x)=aiχEi(x)=aif(s) = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}(x) = a_i \chi_{E_i}(x) = a_if(s)=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​(x)=ai​χEi​​(x)=ai​. Similarly, g(s)=bjg(s) = b_jg(s)=bj​. We have ai=bja_i = b_jai​=bj​ as f≡gf \equiv gf≡g.

Now, let ci,j=ai=bjc_{i,j} = a_i = b_jci,j​=ai​=bj​ if Si,j≠∅S_{i,j} \neq \emptysetSi,j​=∅ and ci,j=0c_{i,j}= 0ci,j​=0 otherwise. Using the fact that {F1,...,Fm}\{ F_1, ..., F_m \}{F1​,...,Fm​} also constitutes a partition of XXX, we have Ei=∪j=1mEi∩FjE_i = \cup_{j = 1}^m E_i \cap F_jEi​=∪j=1m​Ei​∩Fj​ for i∈[1,n]i \in [1, n]i∈[1,n]. By finite additivity of measure,

∫f=∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei)=∑i∈[n]aiμ(∪j=1mEi∩Fj)=∑i∈[n]ai∑j=1mμ(Ei∩Fj)=∑i∈[n]∑j=1mci,jμ(Si,j)\begin{aligned} \int f &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu (E_i ) \\ &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu (\cup_{j=1}^m E_i \cap F_j) \\ &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \sum_{j = 1}^m \mu (E_i \cap F_j) \\ &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } \sum_{j=1}^m c_{i,j} \mu( S_{i,j} ) \end{aligned} ∫f​=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​)=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(∪j=1m​Ei​∩Fj​)=i∈[n]∑​ai​j=1∑m​μ(Ei​∩Fj​)=i∈[n]∑​j=1∑m​ci,j​μ(Si,j​)​

By symmetry, we can show ∫g=∑i∈[n]∑j=1mci,jμ(Si,j)\int g = \sum_{ i \in [n] } \sum_{j=1}^m c_{i,j} \mu( S_{i,j} )∫g=∑i∈[n]​∑j=1m​ci,j​μ(Si,j​), which implies that ∫f=∫g\int f = \int g∫f=∫g, as desired.

NOTE: in the proof we see that ∑i∈[n]∑j=1mci,jμ(Si,j)=∫f<∞\sum_{ i \in [n] } \sum_{j=1}^m c_{i,j} \mu( S_{i,j} ) = \int f < \infty∑i∈[n]​∑j=1m​ci,j​μ(Si,j​)=∫f<∞. It follows that μ(Si,j)=∞→ci,j=0\mu(S_{i, j}) = \infty \rightarrow c_{i,j} = 0μ(Si,j​)=∞→ci,j​=0

■​\blacksquare​■​

Theorem. (Integration on a measurable set).
If EEE is any measurable set and fff is an integrable simple function, then χEf≐χE∑i∈[n]aiχEi\chi_E f \doteq \chi_{E} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}χE​f≐χE​∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​ is also an integrable simple function.

Proof.

χEf=χE∑i∈[n]aiχEi=∑i∈[n]aiχEi∩E\chi_E f = \chi_{E} \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i} = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i \cap E} χE​f=χE​i∈[n]∑​ai​χEi​​=i∈[n]∑​ai​χEi​∩E​

By monotonicity of measure, if ai≠0a_i \neq 0ai​=0, then μ(Ei∩E)≤μ(Ei)<∞\mu(E_i \cap E) \le \mu(E_i) < \inftyμ(Ei​∩E)≤μ(Ei​)<∞. Therefore, χEf\chi_E fχE​f is integrable.

■​\blacksquare​■​

Definition The integration of χEf\chi_E fχE​f is abbreviated as

∫Ef=∫χEf. \int_E f = \int \chi_E f. ∫E​f=∫χE​f.

Now we show some basic properties of simple integration. These properties really inherit from the non-negativity and complete additivity of measure μ\muμ.

Basic Properties

Let f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i }f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​ and g=∑j=1mbjχFjg=\sum_{j=1}^m b_j \chi_{F_j }g=∑j=1m​bj​χFj​​ be two integrable simple functions, and α,β∈R\alpha, \beta \in Rα,β∈R two real values.

  1. Linearity. Integrable simple functions forms a vector space, i.e., ∫αf+βg=a∫f+β∫g​\int \alpha f + \beta g =a \int f + \beta \int g​∫αf+βg=a∫f+β∫g​
    Proof. Define Sij=Ei∩Fj​S_{ij} = E_i \cap F_j​Sij​=Ei​∩Fj​​. Now {Si,j}​\{ S_{i,j} \}​{Si,j​}​ is a partition of X​X​X​. Let ci,j=ai=bj​c_{i,j} = a_i = b_j​ci,j​=ai​=bj​​ if Si,j≠∅​S_{i,j} \neq \emptyset​Si,j​=∅​ and ci,j=0​c_{i,j}= 0​ci,j​=0​ otherwise. Moreover, we have ci,j≠0  ⟹  μ(Si,j)=0​c_{i,j} \neq 0 \implies \mu(S_{i,j} ) = 0​ci,j​=0⟹μ(Si,j​)=0​.

    αf+βg=α∑i∈[n]aiχEi+β∑j=1mbjχFj=∑i,j(α+β)ci,jχSi,j ,∫αf+βg=∑i,j(α+β)ci,jμ(Si,j)=α∑i,jci,jμ(Si,j)+β∑i,jci,jμ(Si,j)=α∫f+β∫g■ \begin{aligned} \alpha f + \beta g &= \alpha \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i} + \beta \sum_{j = 1}^m b_j \chi_{F_j} = \sum_{i,j} (\alpha + \beta) c_{i,j} \chi_{S_{i,j} } \,, \\ \int \alpha f + \beta g &= \sum_{i,j} (\alpha + β) c_{i,j} \mu(S_{i,j}) \\ &= \alpha \sum_{i,j} c_{i,j} \mu(S_{i,j} ) + β \sum_{i,j} c_{i,j} \mu( S_{i,j} ) \\ &= \alpha \int f + \beta \int g \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \blacksquare \end{aligned} αf+βg∫αf+βg​=αi∈[n]∑​ai​χEi​​+βj=1∑m​bj​χFj​​=i,j∑​(α+β)ci,j​χSi,j​​,=i,j∑​(α+β)ci,j​μ(Si,j​)=αi,j∑​ci,j​μ(Si,j​)+βi,j∑​ci,j​μ(Si,j​)=α∫f+β∫g■​

  2. If f≥0 a.e.f \ge 0 \ a.e.f≥0 a.e., then ∫f≥0\int f \ge 0∫f≥0.
    Proof. Let f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​. We claim that aiμ(Ei)≥0a_i \mu(E_i) \ge 0ai​μ(Ei​)≥0 for all i≥1i \ge 1i≥1.

    • If μ(Ei)=∞\mu(E_i) = \inftyμ(Ei​)=∞, then ai=0a_i = 0ai​=0, since fff is measurable.

    • If μ(Ei)>0\mu(E_i) > 0μ(Ei​)>0, then ai≥0a_i \ge 0ai​≥0. Otherwise, we have f<0f < 0f<0 on a set EiE_iEi​ with positive measure, contradicting f≥0 a.e.f \ge 0 \ a.e.f≥0 a.e..

    • If μ(Ei)=0\mu(E_i) = 0μ(Ei​)=0, the claim is trivially true.
      Therefore, ∫f=∑iaiμ(Ei)≥0\int f = \sum_i a_i \mu(E_i ) \ge0∫f=∑i​ai​μ(Ei​)≥0.

    ■\blacksquare■

  3. If f≥g a.ef \ge g \ a.ef≥g a.e, then ∫f≥∫g\int f \ge \int g∫f≥∫g.
    Proof. Observe that

    ∫f−∫g=∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei)−∑j∈[m]bjμ(Fj)=∑i∈[n],j∈[m](ai−bj)μ(Ei∩Fj) \begin{aligned} \int f - \int g &= \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i ) -\sum_{j \in [m] } b_j \mu(F_j ) \\ &= \sum_{i \in [n], j \in [m] } (a_i - b_j ) \mu(E_i \cap F_j) \end{aligned} ∫f−∫g​=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​)−j∈[m]∑​bj​μ(Fj​)=i∈[n],j∈[m]∑​(ai​−bj​)μ(Ei​∩Fj​)​

    and that

    ai−bj<0  ⟹  μ(Ei∩Fj)=0 a_i-b_j < 0 \implies \mu(E_i \cap F_j ) = 0 ai​−bj​<0⟹μ(Ei​∩Fj​)=0

    NOTE: Another way to prove this is by defining h≐f−gh \doteq f - gh≐f−g which if non-negative almost everywhere and use conclusion of (1).
    ■\blacksquare■

  4. ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ is an integrable simple function, and ∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣|\int f|\le \int |f|∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣.
    Proof. Let ∣f∣=∑i∣ai∣χEi|f|=\sum_i |a_i | \chi_{E_i }∣f∣=∑i​∣ai​∣χEi​​. Therefore, ∣ai∣≠0  ⟹  μ(Ei)=0|a_i| ≠ 0 \implies \mu(E_i )=0∣ai​∣=0⟹μ(Ei​)=0. ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ is simple and integrable.

    ∫∣f∣=∑i∣ai∣μ(Ei)≥∣∑iaiμ(Ei)∣=∣∫f∣.■ \int|f| =\sum_i |a_i |\mu(E_i ) \ge \left| \sum_i a_i \mu(E_i ) \right| = \left| \int f \right|. \qquad \blacksquare ∫∣f∣=i∑​∣ai​∣μ(Ei​)≥∣∣∣∣∣∣​i∑​ai​μ(Ei​)∣∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫f∣∣∣∣∣​.■

  5. ∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣\int|f+g | \le \int |f| + \int |g|∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.
    Proof.

    ∫∣f+g∣≤∫(∣f∣+∣g∣)=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.■ \int|f+g| \le \int(|f|+|g|) =\int|f| +\int|g|. \qquad \blacksquare ∫∣f+g∣≤∫(∣f∣+∣g∣)=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.■

  6. If m≤f≤M a.e.m \le f \le M \ a.e.m≤f≤M a.e. on a measurable set EEE with μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞, then mμ(E)≤∫Ef≤Mμ(E)m \mu(E) \le \int_E f \le M \mu(E)mμ(E)≤∫E​f≤Mμ(E).
    Proof. The condition μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞ ensures that m⋅μ(E)<∞m \cdot \mu(E) < \inftym⋅μ(E)<∞. Note that

    ∫Ef=∑iaiμ(Ei∩E) \int_E f=\sum_i a_i \mu(E_i \cap E) ∫E​f=i∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩E)

    and that

    ai<m  ⟹  μ(Ei∩E)=0  ⟹  ∑i(ai−m)μ(Ei∩E)≥0. a_i < m \implies \mu(E_i \cap E) = 0 \implies \sum_i (a_i-m) \mu(E_i \cap E) \ge 0. ai​<m⟹μ(Ei​∩E)=0⟹i∑​(ai​−m)μ(Ei​∩E)≥0.

    In a similar manner we can prove the other inequality.

    NOTE: another way is to utilize that μχE\mu \chi_EμχE​ is simple, integrable μχE≤f\mu \chi_E \le fμχE​≤f almost everywhere.
    ■\blacksquare■

  7. If f≥0, a.e.f \ge 0,\ a.e.f≥0, a.e., and if EEE and FFF are measurable sets with E⊂FE⊂FE⊂F, then ∫Ef≤∫Ff\int_E f \le \int_F f∫E​f≤∫F​f.
    Proof.

    ∫Ef=∑iaiμ(Ei∩E)≤∑iaiμ(Ei∩F)=∫Ff. \int_E f = \sum_i a_i \mu(E_i \cap E) \le \sum_i a_i \mu(E_i \cap F) =\int_F f. ∫E​f=i∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩E)≤i∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩F)=∫F​f.

    Then inequality holds since it is always true that

    aiμ(Ei∩E)≤aiμ(Fi∩E). a_i \mu(E_i \cap E) \le a_i \mu(F_i \cap E). ai​μ(Ei​∩E)≤ai​μ(Fi​∩E).

    • If μ(Ei∩E)≤μ(Ei∩F)=∞\mu(E_i \cap E) \le \mu(E_i \cap F) = \inftyμ(Ei​∩E)≤μ(Ei​∩F)=∞, then ai=0a_i = 0ai​=0.
    • If 0<μ(Ei∩E)≤μ(Ei∩E)<∞0 < \mu(E_i \cap E) \le \mu(E_i \cap E) < \infty0<μ(Ei​∩E)≤μ(Ei​∩E)<∞, then ai≥0a_i \ge 0ai​≥0.
    • If 0=μ(Ei∩E)=μ(Ei∩E)0 = \mu(E_i \cap E) = \mu(E_i \cap E)0=μ(Ei​∩E)=μ(Ei​∩E), then it is trivially true.

    NOTE: another way is to utilize that χEf≤χFf\chi_E f \le \chi_F fχE​f≤χF​f almost everywhere.
    ■​\blacksquare​■​

  8. Monotone convergence. If F=+m≥1FmF = +_{m \ge 1} F_mF=+m≥1​Fm​ is a disjoint union of measurable sets, then

    ∫Ff=∫f⋅(∑m≥1χFm)=∑m≥1∫f⋅χFm=∑m≥1∫Fmf \int_F f = \int f \cdot \Big( \sum_{m \ge 1} \chi_{ F_m } \Big) = \sum_{m \ge 1} \int f \cdot \chi_{ F_m } = \sum_{m \ge 1} \int_{F_m} f ∫F​f=∫f⋅(m≥1∑​χFm​​)=m≥1∑​∫f⋅χFm​​=m≥1∑​∫Fm​​f

    Proof.
    This is a consequence of σ\sigmaσ-additivity of measure. Let f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​,

    ∫Ff=∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei∩F)=∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei∩(+m≥1Fm))=∑i∈[n]aiμ(+m≥1Ei∩Fm)=∑i∈[n]ai∑m≥1μ(Ei∩Fm) by σ-additivity of measure =∑i∈[n]ailim⁡k→∞⁡∑m=1kμ(Ei∩Fm)=lim⁡k→∞⁡∑i∈[n]ai∑m=1kμ(Ei∩Fm) exchange order of limit and finite summation=lim⁡k→∞⁡∑m=1k∑i∈[n]aiμ(Ei∩Fm)=lim⁡k→∞⁡∑i=1k∫Fmf■\begin{aligned} \int_F f &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i \cap F) \\ &=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i \cap ( +_{m \ge 1} F_m )) \\ &=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu( +_{m \ge 1} E_i \cap F_m ) \\ &=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \sum_{m \ge 1} \mu(E_i \cap F_m) & \text{ by $\sigma$-additivity of measure }\\ &=\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} ⁡\sum_{m=1}^k \mu(E_i \cap F_m) \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} ⁡\sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \sum_{m=1}^k \mu(E_i \cap F_m) & \text{ exchange order of limit and finite summation} \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} ⁡ \sum_{m=1}^k \sum_{ i \in [n] } a_i \mu(E_i \cap F_m) \\ &= \lim_{k \rightarrow \infty} ⁡\sum_{i=1}^k \int_{F_m} f \qquad \blacksquare \end{aligned} ∫F​f​=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩F)=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩(+m≥1​Fm​))=i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(+m≥1​Ei​∩Fm​)=i∈[n]∑​ai​m≥1∑​μ(Ei​∩Fm​)=i∈[n]∑​ai​k→∞lim​⁡m=1∑k​μ(Ei​∩Fm​)=k→∞lim​⁡i∈[n]∑​ai​m=1∑k​μ(Ei​∩Fm​)=k→∞lim​⁡m=1∑k​i∈[n]∑​ai​μ(Ei​∩Fm​)=k→∞lim​⁡i=1∑k​∫Fm​​f■​ by σ-additivity of measure  exchange order of limit and finite summation​

  9. Monotone convergence. If F1⊂F2⊂F3⊂...​F_1 \subset F_2 \subset F_3 \subset ...​F1​⊂F2​⊂F3​⊂...​ is a sequence of increasing measurable sets and let F=∪nFn​F = \cup_{n} F_n​F=∪n​Fn​​, then lim⁡n∫Fnf=∫Ff​\lim_n \int_{F_n} f = \int_F f​limn​∫Fn​​f=∫F​f​.
    Proof. Let Fn′=Fn−Fn−1​F_n' = F_n - F_{n - 1}​Fn′​=Fn​−Fn−1​​. The result follows immediately from the previous property.
    ■​\blacksquare​■​

  10. If F1⊃F2⊃F3⊃...F_1 \supset F_2 \supset F_3 \supset ...F1​⊃F2​⊃F3​⊃... is a sequence of decreasing measurable sets and let F=∩nFnF = \cap_{n} F_nF=∩n​Fn​, then lim⁡n∫Fnf=∫Ff\lim_n \int_{F_n} f = \int_F flimn​∫Fn​​f=∫F​f.

    Proof. Let f=∑i=1NaiχEif = \sum_{i = 1}^N a_i \chi_{E_i}f=∑i=1N​ai​χEi​​. It follow that

    ai≠0  ⟹  μ(Ei∩F1)<μ(Ei)<∞. a_i \neq 0 \implies \mu(E_i \cap F_1) < \mu(E_i) < \infty. ai​=0⟹μ(Ei​∩F1​)<μ(Ei​)<∞.

    Using continuity of measure μ\muμ,

    lim⁡nμ(Ei∩Fn)=μ(Ei∩lim⁡nFn)=μ(Ei∩F), \lim_n \mu(E_i \cap F_n) = \mu(E_i \cap \lim_n F_n) = \mu (E_i \cap F), nlim​μ(Ei​∩Fn​)=μ(Ei​∩nlim​Fn​)=μ(Ei​∩F),

    which implies that lim⁡n∫Fnf=∫Ff\lim_n \int_{F_n} f = \int_F flimn​∫Fn​​f=∫F​f.

    Remark. Since fff is integrable, it has nonzero values on a finite support. We don’t even require that μ(F1)<∞\mu(F_1) < \inftyμ(F1​)<∞.
    ■\blacksquare■

  11. Let f=∑i∈[n]aiχEif = \sum_{i \in [n] } a_i \chi_{E_i}f=∑i∈[n]​ai​χEi​​ and define the support N(f)N(f)N(f) of simple integrable function fff to be the set of elements with non-zero values N(f)={x∈X:f(x)≠0}=∪i,ai≠0EiN(f) = \{ x \in X : f(x) \neq 0 \} = \cup_{i, a_i \neq 0} E_iN(f)={x∈X:f(x)=0}=∪i,ai​=0​Ei​, then μ(N(f))≤∞\mu( N(f) ) \le \inftyμ(N(f))≤∞.

    Proof. Since fff is integrable, ai≠0a_i \neq 0ai​=0 implies μ(Ei)<∞\mu(E_i) < \inftyμ(Ei​)<∞. Now

    μ(N(F))=∑1≤i≤n,ai≠0μ(Ei)<∞■\mu( N(F) ) = \sum_{1 \le i \le n, a_i \neq 0} \mu(E_i) < \infty \qquad \qquad \blacksquare μ(N(F))=1≤i≤n,ai​=0∑​μ(Ei​)<∞■

With simple integrable functions as building blocks, we are ready to define integration for functions in general.

Fist we introduce a notation of convergence we need in the following discussion.

Cauchy In Mean

Definition. A sequence {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ of simple functions is called Cauchy in mean if

lim⁡n,m∫∣fn−fm∣=0 \lim_{n, m} \int |f_n - f_m| = 0 n,mlim​∫∣fn​−fm​∣=0

Cauchy in mean does not implies Cauchy almost everywhere. Consider the sequence of functions

  1. χ[0,1/2],χ[1/2,1]\chi_{[0, 1/2]}, \chi_{[1 / 2, 1]}χ[0,1/2]​,χ[1/2,1]​,
  2. χ[0,1/4],χ[1/4,1/2],χ[1/2,3/4],χ[3/4,1]\chi_{ [0, 1 / 4 ] }, \chi_{ [1 / 4, 1 / 2] }, \chi_{ [ 1 / 2, 3 / 4 ] }, \chi_{ [3 / 4, 1] }χ[0,1/4]​,χ[1/4,1/2]​,χ[1/2,3/4]​,χ[3/4,1]​,
  3. …
  4. ...χ[i/2n,(i+1)/2n]...,(i∈{0,1,2,...,2n−1})... \chi_{ [ i / 2^n, (i + 1) / 2^n ] } ...,(i \in \{0, 1, 2, ..., 2^{n} - 1 \} )...χ[i/2n,(i+1)/2n]​...,(i∈{0,1,2,...,2n−1})

They are Cauchy in mean but don’s Cauchy almost everywhere. But it is Cauchy in measure.

Theorem If a sequence {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ of simple functions is Cauchy in mean, it is Cauchy in measure.

Proof. Let hn,m=∣fn−fm∣​h_{n, m} = |f_n - f_m|​hn,m​=∣fn​−fm​∣​. As fn​f_n​fn​​ and fm​f_m​fm​​ are simple and integrable, hn,m​h_{n, m}​hn,m​​ is simple and integrable. Moreover, it is non-negative. We write it as hn,m=∑j∈[k]bjχFj​h_{n,m} = \sum_{j \in [k] } b_j \chi_{F_j}​hn,m​=∑j∈[k]​bj​χFj​​​, where bj≥0​b_j \ge 0​bj​≥0​.
For all δ>0​\delta > 0​δ>0​, bj≥δ>0​b_j \ge \delta > 0​bj​≥δ>0​ implies that μ(Fj)<∞​\mu(F_j) < \infty​μ(Fj​)<∞​.
Now

δ⋅μ({x∈X:hn,m(x)≥δ})=∑j∈[k],bj≥δδ⋅μ(Fj)≤∑j∈[k],bj≥δbjμ(Fj)≤∫hn,m=∫∣fn−fm∣. \begin{aligned} \delta \cdot \mu( \{ x \in X: h_{n,m}(x) \ge \delta\} ) &= \sum_{j \in [k], b_j \ge \delta} \delta \cdot \mu(F_j) \\ &\le \sum_{j \in [k], b_j \ge \delta} b_j \mu(F_j) \\ &\le \int h_{n,m} \\ &= \int |f_n - f_m|. \end{aligned} δ⋅μ({x∈X:hn,m​(x)≥δ})​=j∈[k],bj​≥δ∑​δ⋅μ(Fj​)≤j∈[k],bj​≥δ∑​bj​μ(Fj​)≤∫hn,m​=∫∣fn​−fm​∣.​

Hence, μ({x∈X:hn,m(x)≥δ})≤∫∣fn−fm∣δ\mu( \{ x \in X: h_{n,m}(x) \ge \delta\} ) \le \frac{ \int |f_n - f_m| }{ \delta }μ({x∈X:hn,m​(x)≥δ})≤δ∫∣fn​−fm​∣​. For any fix δ\deltaδ, this can be arbitrary small as n,m→∞n, m \rightarrow \inftyn,m→∞.

■\blacksquare■

NOTE: the converse is not true.

Example Consider this sequence of functions:

{n⋅χ[0,1/n]:n∈N} \{ n \cdot \chi_{[0, 1 / n] } : n \in \mathbf{N} \} {n⋅χ[0,1/n]​:n∈N}

It converges in measure to f≡0f \equiv 0f≡0. But ∫n⋅χ[0,1/n]=1\int n \cdot \chi_{[0, 1 / n] } = 1∫n⋅χ[0,1/n]​=1 for all nnn. lim⁡n∫n⋅χ[0,1/n]≠∫f\lim_n \int n \cdot \chi_{[0, 1 / n] } \neq \int flimn​∫n⋅χ[0,1/n]​=∫f.

The implication here is that we need additional condition more than converge in mean to define the integral for a general function f​f​f​. We need to connect the sequence {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ with f​f​f​, the function we want to define integral. Can we say something like {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ converges to f​f​f​ in mean, i.e., lim⁡n∫∣fn−f∣=0​\lim_n \int |f_n - f| = 0​limn​∫∣fn​−f∣=0​? But we have not define integral of non-simple function yet. Here is how we establish the connection.

General Integrable Functions

Definition. An extended real-valued, measurable function fff, on a measure space (X,Ω,μ)(X, \Omega, \mu)(X,Ω,μ) is said to be integrable if there exists a sequence {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} of integrable simple functions having the following properties:

  1. {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ is a Cauchy sequence in the mean.
  2. lim⁡nfn(x)=f(x)a.e.​\lim_{n} f_n (x) = f(x) \quad a.e.​limn​fn​(x)=f(x)a.e.​.

The integral ∫f​\int f​∫f​ of f​f​f​ is defined as

∫f=lim⁡n∫fn. \int f = \lim_{n} \int f_n. ∫f=nlim​∫fn​.

There are two issues we need to answer for the definition to be well-defined. The first one is that the limit of ∫fn​\int f_n​∫fn​​ indeed exists. Second, we need to show that for any sequence satisfying condition (1) and (2), their integral converges to the same limit.

Theorem (Existence of Limit). lim⁡n∫fn\lim_n \int f_nlimn​∫fn​ exists.

Proof.

∣∫fn−∫fm∣≤∫∣fn−fm∣→0asn,m→∞ \left| \int f_n - \int f_m \right| \le \int | f_n - f_m | \rightarrow 0 \qquad as \quad n, m \rightarrow \infty ∣∣∣∣∣​∫fn​−∫fm​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫∣fn​−fm​∣→0asn,m→∞

Therefore, {∫fn:n∈N}\{ \int f_n : n \in \mathbf{N} \}{∫fn​:n∈N} (note that each element in this set is a real number) is a Cauchy sequence and its limit exists.

■\blacksquare■

Theorem (Uniqueness of Limit). Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} and {gn}\{ g_n \}{gn​} be two Cauchy sequences in the mean of integrable simple functions, such that

lim⁡nfn=lim⁡ngn=fa.e. \lim_n f_n = \lim_n g_n = f \qquad a.e. nlim​fn​=nlim​gn​=fa.e.

Then

lim⁡n∫fn=lim⁡n∫gn. \lim_n \int f_n = \lim_n \int g_n. nlim​∫fn​=nlim​∫gn​.

Proof. Define hn≐fn−gnh_n \doteq f_n - g_nhn​≐fn​−gn​ for n∈Nn \in \mathbf{N}n∈N. As fnf_nfn​ and gng_ngn​ are simple and integrable, hnh_nhn​ is simple and integrable.

Step 1.

We claim that

  1. {hn}\{ h_n \}{hn​} is Cauchy in mean.
  2. lim⁡nhn=0a.e.\lim_n h_n = 0 \quad a.e.limn​hn​=0a.e..

By monotonicity and linearity of integration of simple functions,

∫∣hn−hm∣=∫∣fn−gn−(fm−gm)∣≤∫∣fn−fm∣+∣gn−gm∣=∫∣fn−fm∣+∫∣gn−gm∣ \begin{aligned} \int |h_n - h_m| &= \int | f_n - g_n - (f_m - g_m)| \\ &\le \int |f_n - f_m| + |g_n - g_m| \\ &= \int |f_n - f_m| + \int |g_n - g_m| \end{aligned} ∫∣hn​−hm​∣​=∫∣fn​−gn​−(fm​−gm​)∣≤∫∣fn​−fm​∣+∣gn​−gm​∣=∫∣fn​−fm​∣+∫∣gn​−gm​∣​

The integral can be arbitrary small as n,m→∞n, m \rightarrow \inftyn,m→∞.

The second claim results from the lim⁡nfn=f​\lim_n f_n = f​limn​fn​=f​ and lim⁡ngn=f​\lim_n g_n = f​limn​gn​=f​ a.e.​a.e.​a.e.​.

We are going to prove lim⁡n∫hn=0​\lim_n \int h_n = 0​limn​∫hn​=0​, which then implies

lim⁡n∫(fn−gn)=lim⁡n(∫fn−∫gn)=lim⁡n∫fn−lim⁡n∫gn=0​. \lim_n \int (f_n - g_n) =\lim_n \left( \int f_n - \int g_n \right) = \lim_n \int f_n - \lim_n \int g_n = 0​. nlim​∫(fn​−gn​)=nlim​(∫fn​−∫gn​)=nlim​∫fn​−nlim​∫gn​=0​.

Step 2.

Our goal is to prove that ∫hn→0\int h_n \rightarrow 0∫hn​→0. Specifically,

  • ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N>0\exists N > 0∃N>0, s.t., ∀n>N,∣∫hn∣<O(ϵ)\forall n > N, | \int h_n | < O(\epsilon)∀n>N,∣∫hn​∣<O(ϵ).

The trick here is to restrict the discussion of ∫h\int h∫h on a σ\sigmaσ-finite measurable set.
Define the support Supp(fn)​\mathbb{Supp} ( f_n )​Supp(fn​)​ of fn​f_n​fn​​ to be the set with non-zero values:

Supp(fn)={x∈X:fn(x)≠0} \mathbb{Supp} ( f_n ) = \{ x \in X : f_n(x) \neq 0\} Supp(fn​)={x∈X:fn​(x)=0}

As fn​f_n​fn​​ is a simple integrable function, μ(Supp(fn))<∞​\mu( \mathbb{Supp} ( f_n )) < \infty​μ(Supp(fn​))<∞​. Let En=∪k∈[n](Supp(fk)∪Supp(gk)​)E_n = \cup_{ k \in [n] } \Big( \mathbb{Supp} (f_k) \cup \mathbb{Supp} (g_k)​ \Big)En​=∪k∈[n]​(Supp(fk​)∪Supp(gk​)​) and E=∪nEn​E = \cup_n E_n​E=∪n​En​​.
We have μ(En)<∞​\mu(E_n) < \infty​μ(En​)<∞​, En↑E​E_n \uparrow E​En​↑E​ and E​E​E​ is σ​\sigma​σ​-finite.
By monotone convergence property of simple integrable functions, we have, ∀n\forall n∀n,

∫hn=∫Ehn​ \int h_n = \int_{E} h_n​ ∫hn​=∫E​hn​​

First, as {hn}\{ h_n \}{hn​} is Cauchy in mean, for ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, ∃N1>0\exists N_1 > 0∃N1​>0, s.t, for n,k>N1n, k > N_1n,k>N1​, we have ∫∣hn−hk∣≤ϵ\int |h_n - h_k| \le \epsilon∫∣hn​−hk​∣≤ϵ .
We choose an integer k>N1k > N_1k>N1​. As hkh_khk​ is a simple integrable function, and as Em↑EE_m \uparrow EEm​↑E, it holds that

lim⁡m∫Emhk=∫Ehk=∫hk\lim_m \int_{E_m} h_k = \int_E h_k = \int h_k mlim​∫Em​​hk​=∫E​hk​=∫hk​

For fix kkk, we choose an integer mmm, s…t, ∣∫hk−∫Emhk∣≤ϵ\left| \int h_k - \int_{E_m} h_k \right| \le \epsilon∣∣∣∣​∫hk​−∫Em​​hk​∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ.

For a fix k>N1k > N_1k>N1​, we claim that for any n>N1​n > N_1​n>N1​​, we have ∣∫hn−∫Emhn∣<3ϵ​| \int h_n - \int_{E_m} h_n | < 3\epsilon​∣∫hn​−∫Em​​hn​∣<3ϵ​,

∣∫hn−∫Emhn∣=∣∫hn−∫hk+∫hk−∫Emhk+∫Emhk−∫Emhn∣≤∣∫hn−∫hk∣+∣∫hk−∫Emhk∣+∣∫Emhk−∫Emhn∣≤ϵ+ϵ+∫Em∣hk−hn∣≤3ϵ\begin{aligned} \left| \int h_n - \int_{E_m} h_n \right| &= \left| \int h_n - \int h_k + \int h_k - \int_{E_m} h_k + \int_{E_m} h_k - \int_{E_m} h_n\right| \\ &\le \left| \int h_n - \int h_k \right| + \left| \int h_k - \int_{E_m} h_k \right| + \left| \int_{E_m} h_k - \int_{E_m} h_n \right| \\ &\le \epsilon + \epsilon + \int_{E_m} |h_k - h_n| \\ &\le 3\epsilon \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫hn​−∫Em​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫hn​−∫hk​+∫hk​−∫Em​​hk​+∫Em​​hk​−∫Em​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫hn​−∫hk​∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​∫hk​−∫Em​​hk​∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​∫Em​​hk​−∫Em​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ+ϵ+∫Em​​∣hk​−hn​∣≤3ϵ​

We have successfully restrict our discussion on a set with finite measure. The key here is that ∫Emhn\int_{E_m} h_n∫Em​​hn​ converges uniformly to ∫hn\int h_n∫hn​, as mmm increases, independent of the choice of nnn, as long as {hn}\{ h_n \}{hn​} is Cauchy in mean.

Indeed, what we have shown here is that

lim⁡nlim⁡m∫Emhn=lim⁡mlim⁡n∫Emhn. \lim_n \lim_m \int_{E_m} h_n = \lim_m \lim_n \int_{E_m} h_n. nlim​mlim​∫Em​​hn​=mlim​nlim​∫Em​​hn​.

Second, we prove that

∫Emhn​→0. \int_{E_m} h_n​ \rightarrow 0. ∫Em​​hn​​→0.

So far we have not consider the condition lim⁡nhn=0 a.e.​\lim_n h_n = 0 \ a.e.​limn​hn​=0 a.e.​
It is time to turn to it.
Define

Sn={x∈Em:∣hn(x)∣>ϵ/μ(Em)} S_n = \{ x \in E_m : |h_n(x)| > \epsilon / \mu(E_m) \} Sn​={x∈Em​:∣hn​(x)∣>ϵ/μ(Em​)}

Observe that lim⁡n∪i≥nSn↓\lim_n \cup_{i \ge n} S_n \downarrowlimn​∪i≥n​Sn​↓. As μ(∪i≥1Sn)≤μ(Em)<∞\mu( \cup_{i \ge 1} S_n) \le \mu (E_m) < \inftyμ(∪i≥1​Sn​)≤μ(Em​)<∞, by continuity of μ\muμ,

lim⁡nμ(∪i≥nSn)=μ(lim⁡n∪i≥nSn)=0. \lim_n \mu( \cup_{i \ge n} S_n) = \mu( \lim_n \cup_{i \ge n} S_n) = 0. nlim​μ(∪i≥n​Sn​)=μ(nlim​∪i≥n​Sn​)=0.

As hkh_khk​ is a simple function, it is bounded by some integer K a.e.K \ a.e.K a.e.. As μ(Em)<∞\mu(E_m) < \inftyμ(Em​)<∞, ∃N2>N1\exists N_2 > N_1∃N2​>N1​, s.t., for n>N2n > N_2n>N2​, we have μ(Sn)≤μ(∪i≥nSn)≤ϵ/K\mu(S_n) \le \mu(\cup_{i \ge n} S_n ) \le \epsilon / Kμ(Sn​)≤μ(∪i≥n​Sn​)≤ϵ/K. Now,

∣∫Emhn∣≤∣∫Snhn∣+∣∫Em∖Snhn∣≤∣∫Snhn∣+ϵμ(Em)μ(Em)≤∣∫Snhn∣+ϵ \begin{aligned} \left| \int_{E_m} h_n \right| &\le \left| \int_{S_n} h_n \right| + \left| \int_{E_m \setminus S_n} h_n \right| \\ &\le \left| \int_{S_n} h_n \right| + \frac{\epsilon}{ \mu(E_m) } \mu(E_m) \\ &\le \left| \int_{S_n} h_n \right| + \epsilon \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫Em​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​​≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫Em​∖Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​+μ(Em​)ϵ​μ(Em​)≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​+ϵ​

Finally, we argue that ∣∫Snhn∣​\left| \int_{S_n} h_n \right|​∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣​​ is small enough.

∣∫Snhn∣≤∣∫Snhn−hk+hk∣≤∫∣hn−hk∣+∫Sn∣hk∣≤ϵ+K⋅μ(Sn)≤2ϵ \left| \int_{S_n} h_n \right| \le \left| \int_{S_n} h_n - h_k + h_k \right| \le \int |h_n - h_k| + \int_{S_n} |h_k| \le \epsilon + K \cdot \mu(S_n) \le 2 \epsilon ∣∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫Sn​​hn​−hk​+hk​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫∣hn​−hk​∣+∫Sn​​∣hk​∣≤ϵ+K⋅μ(Sn​)≤2ϵ

Indeed, the technique demonstrated here shows that {∫Ehn}\{ \int_E h_n \}{∫E​hn​} is uniformly absolutely continuous with respect to μ(E)\mu(E)μ(E).

■\blacksquare■

Corollary 1 Let {hn}\{ h_n \}{hn​} be a sequence of simple integrable function that are Cauchy in mean and E1⊂E2⊂E3...E_1 \subset E_2 \subset E_3 ...E1​⊂E2​⊂E3​... a sequence of increasing measurable sets that converge to E=∪i≥1EiE = \cup_{i \ge 1} E_iE=∪i≥1​Ei​. Then ∫Emhn→∫Ehn\int_{E_m} h_n \rightarrow \int_{E} h_n∫Em​​hn​→∫E​hn​ uniformly, i.e., ∀ϵ>0,∃M>0\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists M > 0∀ϵ>0,∃M>0, s.t., for m>Mm > Mm>M, we have

∣∫Emhn−∫Ehn∣≤ϵ \left| \int_{E_m} h_n - \int_E h_n \right| \le \epsilon ∣∣∣∣∣​∫Em​​hn​−∫E​hn​∣∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ

Corollary 2 Let {hn}\{ h_n \}{hn​} be a sequence of simple integrable function that are Cauchy in mean. ∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists \delta > 0∀ϵ>0,∃δ>0, s.t, for any measurable set EEE with μ(E)<δ\mu(E) < \deltaμ(E)<δ, we have ∣∫Ehn∣<ϵ|\int_E h_n| < \epsilon∣∫E​hn​∣<ϵ independent of nnn.

Definition

Let fff be an integrable function and EEE be a measurable set. Then χEf\chi_E fχE​f is integrable and its integral is denoted as

∫χEf=∫Ef \int \chi_E f = \int_E f ∫χE​f=∫E​f

Remark:
If fff is integrable, then there is a sequence simple, integrable function {fn}\{f_n \}{fn​} that are Cauchy in mean and converges to fff almost every. It is easy to see that {χEfn}\{ \chi_E f_n \}{χE​fn​} is simple, integrable, Cauchy in mean and converges to χEf\chi_E fχE​f almost everywhere, therefore χEf\chi_E fχE​f is integrable. An immediately consequence is the following lemma

Lemma 1

∫Efn\int_E f_n∫E​fn​ converges to ∫Ef\int_E f∫E​f uniformly irrespective of EEE.
Proof.
It suffices to show the sequence {∫Efn:n∈N}\{ \int_E f_n : n \in \mathbf{N} \}{∫E​fn​:n∈N} is a uniformly Cauchy irrespectively of EEE,

∣∫Efn−∫Efm∣≤∫E∣fn−fm∣≤∫∣fn−fm∣→0 \left| \int_E f_n - \int_E f_m \right| \le \int_E |f_n - f_m| \le \int |f_n - f_m| \rightarrow 0 ∣∣∣∣∣​∫E​fn​−∫E​fm​∣∣∣∣∣​≤∫E​∣fn​−fm​∣≤∫∣fn​−fm​∣→0

Therefore, for ∀E⊂Ω\forall E \subset \Omega∀E⊂Ω, ∃N>0\exists N > 0∃N>0, for all n，m>Nn，m > Nn，m>N, we have

∣∫Efn−∫Efm∣≤ϵ \left| \int_E f_n - \int_E f_m \right| \le \epsilon ∣∣∣∣∣​∫E​fn​−∫E​fm​∣∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ

Taking limit with respect to mmm, we get lim⁡m∫Efm−ϵ≤∫Efn≤lim⁡m∫Efm+ϵ\lim_m \int_E f_m - \epsilon \le \int_E f_n \le \lim_m \int_E f_m + \epsilonlimm​∫E​fm​−ϵ≤∫E​fn​≤limm​∫E​fm​+ϵ, i.e.,

∣∫Efn−∫Ef∣≤ϵ \left| \int_E f_n - \int_E f \right| \le \epsilon ∣∣∣∣∣​∫E​fn​−∫E​f∣∣∣∣∣​≤ϵ

as desired.

Combining Corollary 2 and Lemma 1, we have the following theorem.

Theorem. Integration as Finite Signed Measure

If fff is integrable, then

λ(E)=∫Ef \lambda(E) = \int_E f λ(E)=∫E​f

is absolute continuous.

Proof.
Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} as defined before. For ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N1>0\exists N_1 > 0∃N1​>0, for all n>N1n > N_1n>N1​, we have ∣∫Ef−∫Efn∣≤ϵ| \int_E f - \int_E f_n | \le \epsilon∣∫E​f−∫E​fn​∣≤ϵ. On the other hand, For ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃δ>0\exists \delta > 0∃δ>0, for all EEE with μ(E)<δ\mu(E) < \deltaμ(E)<δ, we have ∣∫Efn∣<ϵ|\int_E f_n| < \epsilon∣∫E​fn​∣<ϵ. In combination,

∣∫Ef∣≤∣∫Ef−fn∣+∫E∣fn∣≤2ϵ \left| \int_E f \right| \le \left| \int_E f - f_n \right| + \int_E |f_n| \le 2\epsilon ∣∣∣∣∣​∫E​f∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣​∫E​f−fn​∣∣∣∣∣​+∫E​∣fn​∣≤2ϵ

■\blacksquare■

Next we discussion the convergence behavior of a sequence of integrable functions.

Lemma

If {fk}\{ f_k \}{fk​} is a sequence of simple, integrable function that are

  1. Cauchy in the mean,
  2. Converge to fff almost everywhere.

Then

lim⁡k∫∣fk−f∣=0\lim_k \int |f_k - f| = 0 klim​∫∣fk​−f∣=0

Proof.
Note that ∣fk−f∣|f_k - f |∣fk​−f∣ may not be a simple function. To investigate the value of its integral, we need to characterize it according to the definition of integral for general functions. Here is how we do it. For a fix kkk, the sequence {∣fk−fn∣:n∈N}\{ |f_k - f_n| : n \in \mathbf{N} \}{∣fk​−fn​∣:n∈N} is simple, integrable, and converges to ∣fk−f∣|f_k - f |∣fk​−f∣ almost everywhere. Moreover, as {fk}\{ f_k \}{fk​} itself is Cauchy in mean, for ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N>0\exists N > 0∃N>0, s.t., ∀k,n,m>N\forall k, n, m > N∀k,n,m>N,

∫∣∣fk−fn∣−∣fk−fm∣∣≤∫∣fk−fn−(fk−fm)∣=∫∣fm−fn∣≤ϵ \int \left| |f_k - f_n| - |f_k - f_m| \right| \le \int |f_k - f_n - (f_k - f_m)| = \int |f_m - f_n| \le \epsilon ∫∣∣fk​−fn​∣−∣fk​−fm​∣∣≤∫∣fk​−fn​−(fk​−fm​)∣=∫∣fm​−fn​∣≤ϵ

As a consequence {∣fk−fn∣:n∈N}\{|f_k - f_n| : n \in \mathbf{N} \}{∣fk​−fn​∣:n∈N} is Cauchy in the mean. ∣fk−f∣|f_k - f|∣fk​−f∣ is integrable and ∫∣fk−f∣=lim⁡n∫∣fk−fn∣\int |f_k - f| = \lim_n \int |f_k - f_n|∫∣fk​−f∣=limn​∫∣fk​−fn​∣. But for k,n,m>Nk, n, m > Nk,n,m>N,

∫∣fk−f∣=lim⁡m∫∣fk−fm∣≤∫∣fk−fn∣+ϵ≤2ϵ \int |f_k - f| = \lim_m \int |f_k - f_m| \le \int |f_k - f_n| + \epsilon \le 2\epsilon ∫∣fk​−f∣=mlim​∫∣fk​−fm​∣≤∫∣fk​−fn​∣+ϵ≤2ϵ

As ϵ\epsilonϵ could be arbitrary small, we have lim⁡k∫∣fk−f∣=0\lim_k \int |f_k - f| = 0limk​∫∣fk​−f∣=0.

■\blacksquare■

Theorem

If gk{g_k}gk​ is a sequence of integrable functions satisfying the conditions

  1. gk{g_k}gk​ is a Cauchy sequence in the mean.
  2. gk{g_k}gk​ converges in measure to fff.

then fff is integrable and ∫f=lim⁡⁡k∫gk\int f = \lim⁡_k \int g_k∫f=lim⁡k​∫gk​.

Proof. For each gkg_kgk​, there is a sequence {gkm:m∈N}\{ g_{km} : m ∈ \mathbf{N} \}{gkm​:m∈N} simple integrable functions,

  1. {gkm}\{ g_{km} \}{gkm​} is a Cauchy sequence in the mean.

  2. {gkm}\{ g_{km} \}{gkm​} converges in measure to gkg_kgk​.

  3. ∫gk=lim⁡m⁡∫gkm\int g_k = \lim_m ⁡\int g_{km}∫gk​=limm​⁡∫gkm​

For fix k​k​k​, we choose such an integer m​m​m​, such that ∫∣gk−∫gkm∣≤1/k​\int |g_k - \int g_{k m} |\le 1 / k​∫∣gk​−∫gkm​∣≤1/k​ and μ({x:∣gk(x)−gkm(x)∣≥1/k})≤1/k​\mu(\{ x:|g_k (x) - g_{km} (x) | \ge 1 / k \} ) \le 1 / k​μ({x:∣gk​(x)−gkm​(x)∣≥1/k})≤1/k​. For convenience, denote gkm​g_{k m}​gkm​​ as fk​f_k​fk​​. Now we claim the sequence {fk}​\{ f_{k} \}​{fk​}​ of simple integrable functions satisfies

  1. is a Cauchy sequence in the mean.
  2. converges to f​f​f​ in measure.

The first one result from the fact {gk}\{ g_k \}{gk​} is Cauchy sequence in the mean and triangle inequality

∫∣fm−fn∣≤∫∣fm−gm∣+∣gm−gn∣+∣gn−fn∣≤∫∣fm−gm∣+∫∣gm−gn∣+∫∣gn−fn∣≤1m+∫∣gm−gn∣+1n→0as n,m→∞\begin{aligned} \int | f_{m} - f_{n} | &\le \int | f_{m} - g_m | +| g_m - g_n |+| g_n - f_n | \\ &\le \int | f_{m} - g_m | + \int | g_m - g_n | + \int | g_n - f_n | \\ &\le \frac{1}{m} + \int | g_m - g_n | + \frac{1}{n} \\ &\rightarrow 0 \quad \text{as } n, m \rightarrow \infty \end{aligned} ∫∣fm​−fn​∣​≤∫∣fm​−gm​∣+∣gm​−gn​∣+∣gn​−fn​∣≤∫∣fm​−gm​∣+∫∣gm​−gn​∣+∫∣gn​−fn​∣≤m1​+∫∣gm​−gn​∣+n1​→0as n,m→∞​

The second claim also results from triangle inequality. For any δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, ∃1/k≤δ​\exists 1 / k \le \delta​∃1/k≤δ​, s.t.,

μ({x∈X:∣fk−f∣≥δ})≤μ({x∈X:∣fk−gk∣≥δ})+μ({x∈X:∣gk−f∣≥δ})≤1/k+μ({x∈X:∣gk−f∣≥δ})→0as k→∞\begin{aligned} \mu(\{ x \in X: |f_k - f | \ge \delta \} ) &\le \mu(\{ x \in X: |f_k - g_k | \ge \delta \} ) + \mu(\{ x \in X: |g_k - f | \ge \delta \} ) \\ &\le 1/k + \mu(\{ x \in X: |g_k - f | \ge \delta \} ) \\ &\rightarrow 0 \quad \text{as } k \rightarrow \infty \end{aligned} μ({x∈X:∣fk​−f∣≥δ})​≤μ({x∈X:∣fk​−gk​∣≥δ})+μ({x∈X:∣gk​−f∣≥δ})≤1/k+μ({x∈X:∣gk​−f∣≥δ})→0as k→∞​

■\blacksquare■

Theorem. Lebesgue’s Bounded Convergence Theorem

Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} be a sequence of integrable functions that converges either in measure or a.e. to a measurable function fff. If ∣fn(x)∣≤g(x) a.e.|f_n(x)| \le g(x) \ a.e.∣fn​(x)∣≤g(x) a.e. for all nnn, where ggg is an integrable function, then fff is integrable.

Note: compared to definition of fff being integrable,

  1. We no longer require {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ to be simple functions.
  2. We no longer require {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} to be Cauchy in mean.

Proof.

It suffices to show {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} is a Cauchy sequence in mean.

  1. Each {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} can be approximated by a sequence of simple functions. Therefore, we can find a σ\sigmaσ-finite measurable set FnF_nFn​ such that ∫Fnfn=∫fn\int_{F_n} f_n = \int f_n∫Fn​​fn​=∫fn​. Similarly, we can find a σ\sigmaσ finite measurable set GGG such that ∫Gg=∫g\int_G g = \int g∫G​g=∫g.

  2. The measurable set E=(∪nFn)∪GE = (\cup_n F_n) \cup GE=(∪n​Fn​)∪G is σ\sigmaσ finite. There exists a sequence of increasing, finite measurable set E1⊂E2⊂E3...E_1 \subset E_2 \subset E_3 ...E1​⊂E2​⊂E3​... which satisfies En↑EE_n \uparrow EEn​↑E.

  3. As ∫Eg<∞​\int_E g < \infty​∫E​g<∞​, and lim⁡m∫Emg=∫Eg​\lim_m \int_{E_m} g = \int_E g​limm​∫Em​​g=∫E​g​, ∀ϵ>0,∃m>0​\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists m > 0​∀ϵ>0,∃m>0​, s.t., ∣∫E∖Emg∣≤ϵ​|\int_{E \setminus E_m} g | \le \epsilon​∣∫E∖Em​​g∣≤ϵ​.

  4. The integral of ∣fn−fm∣​|f_n - f_m|​∣fn​−fm​∣​ outside Em​E_m​Em​​ is small: ∫E∖Em∣fn−fm∣≤∫E∖Em∣fn∣+∣fm∣≤2∫E∖Emg≤2ϵ​\int_{E \setminus E_m} |f_n - f_m| \le \int_{E \setminus E_m} |f_n| + |f_m| \le 2 \int_{E \setminus E_m} g \le 2 \epsilon​∫E∖Em​​∣fn​−fm​∣≤∫E∖Em​​∣fn​∣+∣fm​∣≤2∫E∖Em​​g≤2ϵ​.

  5. Consider the integral inside the finite set EmE_mEm​. Define Sk≐{x∈Em:∣fi(x)−fj(x)∣≥ϵ/μ(Em) for all i,j≥k}S_k \doteq \{ x \in E_m : |f_i(x) - f_j(x)| \ge \epsilon / \mu(E_m) \text{ for all } i, j \ge k\}Sk​≐{x∈Em​:∣fi​(x)−fj​(x)∣≥ϵ/μ(Em​) for all i,j≥k}. As {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} converges to fff in measure or a.e., and μ(Em)<∞\mu(E_m) < \inftyμ(Em​)<∞, μ(Sk)→μ(Em)\mu(S_k) \rightarrow \mu(E_m)μ(Sk​)→μ(Em​). We can choose an kkk, s.t., μ(Em∖Sk)≤δ\mu(E_m \setminus S_k) \le \deltaμ(Em​∖Sk​)≤δ, where δ\deltaδ is chosen with ∫Em∖Skg<ϵ\int_{E_m \setminus S_k} g < \epsilon∫Em​∖Sk​​g<ϵ. Such δ\deltaδ exists because ggg is integrable, therefore ∫Em∖Skg\int_{E_m \setminus S_k} g∫Em​∖Sk​​g absolute continuous with respect to μ(Em Sk)\mu(E_m \ S_k)μ(Em​ Sk​). Now, for n,m≥kn, m \ge kn,m≥k,

  6. ∫Em∣fn−fm∣=∫Sk∣fn−fm∣+∫Em∖Sk∣fn−fm∣≤ϵμ(Em)μ(Em)+2∫Em∖Skg≤3ϵ​\int_{E_m} | f_n - f_m | = \int_{S_k} |f_n - f_m| + \int_{E_m \setminus S_k} |f_n - f_m| \le \frac{\epsilon}{\mu(E_m) }\mu(E_m) + 2 \int_{E_m \setminus S_k} g \le 3 \epsilon​∫Em​​∣fn​−fm​∣=∫Sk​​∣fn​−fm​∣+∫Em​∖Sk​​∣fn​−fm​∣≤μ(Em​)ϵ​μ(Em​)+2∫Em​∖Sk​​g≤3ϵ​

  7. ∫E∣fn−fm∣=∫E∖Em∣fn−fm∣+∫Em∣fn−fm∣≤2ϵ+3ϵ=5ϵ​\int_E |f_n - f_m| = \int_{E \setminus E_m} |f_n - f_m| + \int_{E_m} | f_n - f_m| \le 2 \epsilon + 3 \epsilon = 5 \epsilon​∫E​∣fn​−fm​∣=∫E∖Em​​∣fn​−fm​∣+∫Em​​∣fn​−fm​∣≤2ϵ+3ϵ=5ϵ​.

■\blacksquare■

Theorem. Lebesgue’s Monotone Convergence Theorem

Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} be a monotone increasing sequence of non-negative integrable functions that converges almost everywhere to fff. Then

lim⁡n∫fn=∫f \lim_n \int f_n = \int f nlim​∫fn​=∫f

Note: compared to the definition of integral of fff

  1. We no longer require {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} to be simple functions.
  2. ∫fn\int f_n∫fn​ might diverge to ∞\infty∞. In this case, fff is not integrable as ∫f=∞\int f = \infty∫f=∞. But the equation still holds.

Proof.
First consider the case ∫fn\int f_n∫fn​ is unbounded. Then ∫f=∫nfn=∞\int f = \int_n f_n = \infty∫f=∫n​fn​=∞ by definition.

Otherwise, suppose lim⁡n∫fn\lim_n \int f_nlimn​∫fn​ is bounded. Then ∫fn\int f_n∫fn​ is an increasing sequence that converges to a real number. It follows that for n>mn > mn>m, then fn>fmf_n > f_mfn​>fm​. Consequently

∫∣fn−fm∣=∫fn−fm=∫fn−∫fm→0 as n,m→∞ \int |f_n - f_m| = \int f_n - f_m = \int f_n - \int f_m \rightarrow 0 \qquad \text{ as } n, m \rightarrow \infty ∫∣fn​−fm​∣=∫fn​−fm​=∫fn​−∫fm​→0 as n,m→∞

Thus, {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} is a Cauchy sequence in the mean. Hence, fff is integrable and lim⁡n∫fn=∫f\lim_n \int f_n = \int flimn​∫fn​=∫f.

Theorem. Fatou 's Lemma

Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} be a sequence of non-negative and integrable functions. Then

∫lim inf⁡nfn≤lim inf⁡n∫fn \int \liminf_n f_n \le \liminf_n \int f_n ∫nliminf​fn​≤nliminf​∫fn​

Proof.
Let hn=inf⁡k≥nfkh_n = \inf_{k \ge n} f_khn​=infk≥n​fk​. Then hnh_nhn​ is a sequence of monotone increasing measurable functions that converges to lim inf⁡nhn\liminf_n h_nliminfn​hn​. By monotone convergence theorem,

∫lim⁡nhn=lim⁡n∫hn\int \lim_n h_n = \lim_n \int h_n ∫nlim​hn​=nlim​∫hn​

On the other hand, hn=inf⁡k≥nfk≤fmh_n = \inf_{k \ge n} f_k \le f_mhn​=infk≥n​fk​≤fm​ for all m≥nm \ge nm≥n. It follows that

∫hn≤inf⁡m≥n∫fmlim⁡n∫hn≤lim⁡ninf⁡m≥n∫fm=lim inf⁡n∫fn \begin{aligned} \int h_n &\le \inf_{m \ge n} \int f_m \\ \lim_n \int h_n &\le \lim_n \inf_{m \ge n} \int f_m = \liminf_n \int f_n \end{aligned} ∫hn​nlim​∫hn​​≤m≥ninf​∫fm​≤nlim​m≥ninf​∫fm​=nliminf​∫fn​​

Combining the two equations we obtain the Fatou 's lemma.

Basic Properties

Let fff and ggg be two integrable functions, and α,β∈R\alpha, \beta \in Rα,β∈R two real values.

  1. Linearity. Integrable functions forms a vector space, i.e., ∫αf+βg=α∫f+β∫g\int \alpha f + \beta g = \alpha \int f + \beta \int g∫αf+βg=α∫f+β∫g
    Proof. Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} and {gn}\{ g_n \}{gn​} be two sequence of simple, integrable functions that define the integral of fff and ggg respectively.
    Then {αfn+βgn}\{ \alpha f_n + \beta g_n \}{αfn​+βgn​} is a sequence of simple, integrable functions that are Cauchy in the mean and converges to αf+βg\alpha f + \beta gαf+βg almost everywhere (assuming that lim⁡nfn=f a.e.\lim_n f_n = f \ a.e.limn​fn​=f a.e. and lim⁡ngn=g a.e.\lim_n g_n = g \ a.e.limn​gn​=g a.e.).

    ∫αf+βg=lim⁡n∫αfn+βgn=αlim⁡n∫fn+βlim⁡n∫gn=α∫f+β∫g. \begin{aligned} \int \alpha f + \beta g &= \lim_n \int \alpha f_n + \beta g_n \\ &= \alpha \lim_n \int f_n + \beta \lim_n \int g_n = \alpha \int f + \beta \int g. \end{aligned} ∫αf+βg​=nlim​∫αfn​+βgn​=αnlim​∫fn​+βnlim​∫gn​=α∫f+β∫g.​

    ■\blacksquare■

  2. If f≥0 a.e.​f \ge 0 \ a.e.​f≥0 a.e.​, then ∫f≥0​\int f \ge 0​∫f≥0​.
    Proof. Let {fn}​\{ f_n \}​{fn​}​ be a sequence of simple, integrable function that are Cauchy in mean and lim⁡nfn=f a.e.​\lim_n f_n = f \ a.e.​limn​fn​=f a.e.​. Then lim⁡n∫fn=∫f​\lim_n \int f_n = \int f​limn​∫fn​=∫f​.
    As f≥0 a.e.​f \ge 0 \ a.e.​f≥0 a.e.​, {∣fn∣}​\{ |f_n| \}​{∣fn​∣}​ converges to f​f​f​ almost everywhere.
    Moreover, {∣fn∣}​\{ |f_n| \}​{∣fn​∣}​ is simple, integrable and Cauchy in the mean.
    Therefore, we also have

    ∫f=lim⁡n∫∣fn∣≥0 \int f = \lim_n \int |f_n| \ge 0 ∫f=nlim​∫∣fn​∣≥0

    ■\blacksquare■

  3. If f≥g a.ef \ge g \ a.ef≥g a.e, then ∫f≥∫g\int f \ge \int g∫f≥∫g.
    Proof. Let h=f−gh = f - gh=f−g, then h≥0 a.e.h \ge 0 \ a.e.h≥0 a.e.. By property 2 and 1, we obtain

    ∫h=∫f−g=∫f−∫g≥0 \int h = \int f - g = \int f - \int g \ge 0 ∫h=∫f−g=∫f−∫g≥0

    NOTE: it is also possible to prove this from scratch. Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} and {gn}\{ g_n \}{gn​} be two sequence of simple, integrable functions that define the integral of fff and ggg respectively. Define hn=fn−gnh_n = f_n - g_nhn​=fn​−gn​ be a sequence of simple, integrable functions that are Cauchy in the mean. Moreover, we have lim⁡hn≥0 a.e.\lim h_n \ge 0 \ a.e.limhn​≥0 a.e.. We need to show that ∫h=lim⁡n∫hn≥0\int h = \lim_n \int h_n \ge 0∫h=limn​∫hn​≥0.

    As before, we would like to restrict our discussion on a σ\sigmaσ-finite measurable set. Define Fm=∪i=1mN(fi)∪∪i=1mN(gi)F_m = \cup_{i = 1}^m N(f_i) \cup \cup_{i = 1}^m N(g_i)Fm​=∪i=1m​N(fi​)∪∪i=1m​N(gi​) and F=∪m=1∞FmF = \cup_{m = 1}^\infty F_mF=∪m=1∞​Fm​. Clearly Fm↑FF_m \uparrow FFm​↑F and ∫h=∫Fh\int h = \int_{F} h∫h=∫F​h.

    On the other hand,

    ∫h≥∫hn−∣∫hn−∫h∣=∫Fmhn−∫Fmhn+∫Fmhk−∫Fmhk+∫hk−∫hk+∫hn−∣∫hn−∫h∣≥∫Fmhn−∣∫Fmhn−∫Fmhk∣−∣∫Fmhk−∫hk∣−∣∫hk−∫hn∣−∣∫hn−∫h∣≥∫Fmhn−∫∣hn−hk∣−∣∫Fmhk−∫hk∣−∫∣hk−hn∣−∫∣hk−hn∣ \begin{aligned} \int h & \ge \int h_n - \left| \int h_n - \int h \right| \\ &= \int_{F_m} h_n - \int_{F_m} h_n + \int_{F_m} h_k - \int_{F_m} h_k + \int h_k - \int h_k + \int h_n - |\int h_n - \int h| \\ &\ge \int_{F_m} h_n - \left| \int_{F_m} h_n - \int_{F_m} h_k \right| - \left| \int_{F_m} h_k - \int h_k \right| - \left| \int h_k - \int h_n \right| - \left| \int h_n - \int h \right| \\ &\ge \int_{F_m} h_n - \int \left| h_n - h_k \right| - \left| \int_{F_m} h_k - \int h_k \right| - \int \left| h_k - h_n \right| - \int \left| h_k - h_n \right| \end{aligned} ∫h​≥∫hn​−∣∣∣∣∣​∫hn​−∫h∣∣∣∣∣​=∫Fm​​hn​−∫Fm​​hn​+∫Fm​​hk​−∫Fm​​hk​+∫hk​−∫hk​+∫hn​−∣∫hn​−∫h∣≥∫Fm​​hn​−∣∣∣∣∣​∫Fm​​hn​−∫Fm​​hk​∣∣∣∣∣​−∣∣∣∣∣​∫Fm​​hk​−∫hk​∣∣∣∣∣​−∣∣∣∣∣​∫hk​−∫hn​∣∣∣∣∣​−∣∣∣∣∣​∫hn​−∫h∣∣∣∣∣​≥∫Fm​​hn​−∫∣hn​−hk​∣−∣∣∣∣∣​∫Fm​​hk​−∫hk​∣∣∣∣∣​−∫∣hk​−hn​∣−∫∣hk​−hn​∣​

    Since {hn}\{h_n\}{hn​} is Cauchy in mean, we can take sufficient large NNN, s.t., for n,k≥Nn, k \ge Nn,k≥N, ∫∣hk−hn∣≤ϵ\int |h_k - h_n| \le \epsilon∫∣hk​−hn​∣≤ϵ. Now we choose an k≥Nk \ge Nk≥N and fix its value. Further, as Fm↑FF_m \uparrow FFm​↑F, we can choose an mmm, s.t., ∣∫Fmhk−∫hk∣≤ϵ|\int_{F_m} h_k - \int h_k| \le \epsilon∣∫Fm​​hk​−∫hk​∣≤ϵ. It follow

    ∫h≥∫Fmhn−3ϵ\int h \ge \int_{F_m} h_n - 3 \epsilon ∫h≥∫Fm​​hn​−3ϵ

    It suffice to show ∫Fmhn\int_{F_m} h_n∫Fm​​hn​ is sufficient large on a measurable set FmF_mFm​ with finite measure for large enough nnn. Define Sn≐{x∈Fm:hi(x)≥−ϵ/μ(Fm) for all i≥n}S_n \doteq \{ x \in F_m : h_i (x) \ge - \epsilon / \mu(F_m) \text{ for all } i \ge n \}Sn​≐{x∈Fm​:hi​(x)≥−ϵ/μ(Fm​) for all i≥n}. As lim⁡nh≥0 a.e.\lim_n h \ge 0 \ a.e.limn​h≥0 a.e., Sn↑S_n \uparrowSn​↑ and ∃n\exists n∃n s.t., μ(Fm∖Sn)≤δ\mu(F_m \setminus S_n) \le \deltaμ(Fm​∖Sn​)≤δ, where δ\deltaδ is chosen s.t., ∫Fm∖Sn∣hk∣≤ϵ\int_{F_m \setminus S_n} |h_k| \le \epsilon∫Fm​∖Sn​​∣hk​∣≤ϵ. Such δ\deltaδ exists since hkh_khk​ is simple and integrable. For such an nnn,

    ∫h≥∫Snhn+∫Fm∖Snhn−3ϵ≥−ϵμ(Fm)μ(Fm)+∫Fm∖Snhk−∫Fm∖Snhk+∫Fm∖Snhn−3ϵ≥−4ϵ−∣∫Fm∖Snhk∣−∫∣hk−hn∣≥−6ϵ \begin{aligned} \int h & \ge \int_{S_n} h_n + \int_{F_m \setminus S_n} h_n - 3 \epsilon \\ &\ge \frac{-\epsilon}{\mu(F_m)}\mu(F_m) + \int_{F_m \setminus S_n} h_k - \int_{F_m \setminus S_n} h_k + \int_{F_m \setminus S_n} h_n - 3 \epsilon \\ &\ge -4 \epsilon - \left| \int_{F_m \setminus S_n} h_k \right| - \int |h_k - h_n| \\ &\ge -6 \epsilon \end{aligned} ∫h​≥∫Sn​​hn​+∫Fm​∖Sn​​hn​−3ϵ≥μ(Fm​)−ϵ​μ(Fm​)+∫Fm​∖Sn​​hk​−∫Fm​∖Sn​​hk​+∫Fm​∖Sn​​hn​−3ϵ≥−4ϵ−∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫Fm​∖Sn​​hk​∣∣∣∣∣∣​−∫∣hk​−hn​∣≥−6ϵ​

    As ϵ\epsilonϵ could be arbitrary value, it must be true that ∫h≥0\int h \ge 0∫h≥0.

    ■\blacksquare■

  4. ∣f∣|f|∣f∣ is an integrable function, and ∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣|\int f| \le \int |f|∣∫f∣≤∫∣f∣.
    Proof. Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} be a sequence of simple, integrable function that are Cauchy in mean and lim⁡nfn=f a.e.\lim_n f_n = f \ a.e.limn​fn​=f a.e. Then Let {∣fn∣}\{ |f_n| \}{∣fn​∣} be a sequence of simple, integrable function that are Cauchy in mean and lim⁡n∣fn∣=∣f∣ a.e.​\lim_n |f_n| = |f| \ a.e.​limn​∣fn​∣=∣f∣ a.e.​

    ∫∣f∣=lim⁡n∫∣fn∣≥±lim⁡n∫fn=±∫f \int|f| = \lim_n \int |f_n| \ge \pm \lim_n \int f_n = \pm \int f ∫∣f∣=nlim​∫∣fn​∣≥±nlim​∫fn​=±∫f

    ■\blacksquare■

  5. ∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣\int | f + g | \le \int |f| + \int |g|∫∣f+g∣≤∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.
    Proof. ∫∣f+g∣≤∫(∣f∣+∣g∣)=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.■\int|f+g| \le \int(|f|+|g|) =\int|f| +\int|g|. \qquad \blacksquare∫∣f+g∣≤∫(∣f∣+∣g∣)=∫∣f∣+∫∣g∣.■

  6. If m≤f≤M a.e.m \le f \le M \ a.e.m≤f≤M a.e. on a measurable set EEE with μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞, then mμ(E)≤∫Ef≤Mμ(E)m \mu(E) \le \int_E f \le M \mu(E)mμ(E)≤∫E​f≤Mμ(E).
    Proof. The condition μ(E)<∞\mu(E) < \inftyμ(E)<∞ ensures that mμ(E)<∞m \mu(E) < \inftymμ(E)<∞.
    Then utilize that μχE\mu \chi_EμχE​ is simple, integrable μχE≤f⋅χE\mu \chi_E \le f \cdot \chi_EμχE​≤f⋅χE​ almost everywhere.
    ■\blacksquare■

  7. If f≥0, a.e.f \ge 0,\ a.e.f≥0, a.e., and if EEE and FFF are measurable sets with E⊂FE⊂FE⊂F, then ∫Ef≤∫Ff\int_E f \le \int_F f∫E​f≤∫F​f.
    Proof.
    Utilize that χEf≤χFf\chi_E f \le \chi_F fχE​f≤χF​f almost everywhere.
    ■\blacksquare■

  8. If F=+m≥1FnF = +_{m \ge 1} F_nF=+m≥1​Fn​ is a disjoint union of measurable sets, then
    ∫Ff=∑m≥1∫Fmf\int_F f=\sum_{m \ge 1} \int_{F_m} f∫F​f=∑m≥1​∫Fm​​f.
    Proof. Let {fn}\{ f_n \}{fn​} be a sequence of simple, integrable function that are Cauchy in mean and lim⁡nfn=f a.e.\lim_n f_n = f \ a.e.limn​fn​=f a.e.. What we are going to prove is

    lim⁡nlim⁡k∫∪m=1kFmfn=lim⁡klim⁡n∫∪m=1kFmfn=lim⁡k∑m=1k∫Fmf\lim_n \lim_k \int_{\cup_{m = 1}^k F_m} f_n = \lim_k \lim_n \int_{\cup_{m = 1}^k F_m} f_n = \lim_k \sum_{m = 1}^k \int_{F_m} f nlim​klim​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​=klim​nlim​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​=klim​m=1∑k​∫Fm​​f

    The exchange order of limit is justified as {fn}​\{f_n\}​{fn​}​ is a sequence that is Cauchy in mean:

    ∣∫Ff∣=∣∫Ffn∣+∣∫Ffn−∫f∣≤∣∫∪m=1kFmfn∣+∣∫∪m=1kFmfn−∫Ffn∣+∣∫Ffn−∫f∣≤∣∫∪m=1kFmf∣+∣∫∪m=1kFmf−∫∪m=1kFmfn∣+∣∫∪m=1kFmfn−∫Ffn∣+∣∫Ffn−∫f∣≤∣∑m=1k∫Fmf∣+ϵ+∣∫∪m=1kFmfn−∫Ffn∣+ϵ \begin{aligned} \left| \int_F f \right| &= \left| \int_F f_n \right| + \left| \int_F f_n - \int f \right| \\ &\le \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f_n \right| + \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f_n - \int_F f_n \right| + \left| \int_F f_n - \int f \right| \\ &\le \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f \right| + \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f - \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f_n \right| + \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f_n - \int_F f_n \right| + \left| \int_F f_n - \int f \right| \\ &\le \left| \sum_{m=1}^k \int_{F_m} f \right| + \epsilon + \left| \int_{\cup_{m=1}^k F_m} f_n - \int_F f_n \right| + \epsilon \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫F​f∣∣∣∣∣​​=∣∣∣∣∣​∫F​fn​∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​∫F​fn​−∫f∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​−∫F​fn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​∫F​fn​−∫f∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​f∣∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​f−∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​−∫F​fn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​+∣∣∣∣∣​∫F​fn​−∫f∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣∣∣∣∣∣​m=1∑k​∫Fm​​f∣∣∣∣∣∣​+ϵ+∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫∪m=1k​Fm​​fn​−∫F​fn​∣∣∣∣∣∣​+ϵ​

    for large enough nnn. The conclusion follows as m→∞m \rightarrow \inftym→∞.

    ■\blacksquare■.

  9. If F1⊂F2⊂F3⊂...F_1 \subset F_2 \subset F_3 \subset ...F1​⊂F2​⊂F3​⊂... is a sequence of increasing measurable sets and let F=∪nFnF = \cup_{n} F_nF=∪n​Fn​, then lim⁡n∫Fnf=∫Ff\lim_n \int_{F_n} f = \int_F flimn​∫Fn​​f=∫F​f.
    Proof. Let Fn′=Fn−Fn−1F_n' = F_n - F_{n - 1}Fn′​=Fn​−Fn−1​. The result follows immediately from the previous property.

    ■\blacksquare■

  10. If F1⊃F2⊃F3⊃...F_1 \supset F_2 \supset F_3 \supset ...F1​⊃F2​⊃F3​⊃... is a sequence of decreasing measurable sets and let F=∩nFnF = \cap_{n} F_nF=∩n​Fn​, then lim⁡n∫Fnf=∫Ff\lim_n \int_{F_n} f = \int_F flimn​∫Fn​​f=∫F​f.
    Proof.
    Let Fn=Fn−Fn+1F_n = F_{n} - F_{n + 1}Fn​=Fn​−Fn+1​ for n≥1n \ge 1n≥1 and F=∩nFnF = \cap_n F_nF=∩n​Fn​. Then F1=(∪nFn′)∪FF_1 = (\cup_{n} F_n') \cup FF1​=(∪n​Fn′​)∪F

    ∑n=1∞∫Fn′f+∫Ff=∫F1f\sum_{n = 1}^\infty \int_{F_n'} f + \int_F f = \int_{F_1} f n=1∑∞​∫Fn′​​f+∫F​f=∫F1​​f

    The fact that fff is integrable implies ∫F1f<∞\int_{F_1} f < \infty∫F1​​f<∞. Hence

    ∫Ff=∫F1f−∑n=1∞∫Fn′f=lim⁡k(∫F1f−∑n=1k∫Fn′f)=lim⁡k∫Fk+1f \int_F f = \int_{F_1} f - \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \int_{F_n'} f = \lim_k \left(\int_{F_1} f - \sum_{n = 1}^k \int_{F_n'} f \right) = \lim_k \int_{F_{k + 1} } f ∫F​f=∫F1​​f−n=1∑∞​∫Fn′​​f=klim​(∫F1​​f−n=1∑k​∫Fn′​​f)=klim​∫Fk+1​​f

    ■\blacksquare■

  11. Let fff be an integrable function. Then for ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, the set E={x∈X:f(x)>ϵ}E = \{ x \in X : f(x) > \epsilon \}E={x∈X:f(x)>ϵ} has finite measure and μ(E)≤∫Efϵ\mu(E) \le \frac{\int_E f}{\epsilon}μ(E)≤ϵ∫E​f​.
    Proof. Clearly EEE is measurable. Further, consider the set F={x∈X:f(x)≠0}F = \{ x \in X : f(x) \neq 0 \}F={x∈X:f(x)=0}, which is σ\sigmaσ finite. We can rewrite it as an increasing sequence of finite measurable set F1⊂F2⊂F3...F_1 \subset F_2 \subset F_3 ...F1​⊂F2​⊂F3​..., s.t., Fn↑FF_n \uparrow FFn​↑F. As μ(E∩Fn)≤∞\mu(E \cap F_n) \le \inftyμ(E∩Fn​)≤∞, ϵχE∩Fn\epsilon \chi_{E \cap F_n}ϵχE∩Fn​​ is integrable. By monotonicity of integration,

    ϵμ(E∩Fn)=∫ϵχE∩Fn≤∫fχE∩Fn≤∫Ef<∞ \epsilon \mu(E \cap F_n) = \int \epsilon \chi_{E \cap F_n} \le \int f \chi_{E \cap F_n} \le \int_E f < \infty ϵμ(E∩Fn​)=∫ϵχE∩Fn​​≤∫fχE∩Fn​​≤∫E​f<∞

    Now we see that μ(E∩Fn)≤∫fϵ\mu(E \cap F_n) \le \frac{\int f}{\epsilon }μ(E∩Fn​)≤ϵ∫f​. Taking the limit of n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞, we obtain the desired result.
    ■\blacksquare■
